Defending Against Data Reconstruction Attacks in Federated Learning:
An Information Theory Approach

Qi Tana, Qi Lib, Yi Zhaoc, 🖂, Zhuotao Liub, Xiaobing Guod, and Ke Xua, 🖂

aDepartment of Computer Science and Technology, Tsinghua University
bInstitute for Network Science and Cyberspace, Tsinghua University
cSchool of Cyberspace Science and Technology, Beijing Institute of Technology
dLenovo Research
Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) trains a black-box and high-dimensional model among different clients by exchanging parameters instead of direct data sharing, which mitigates the privacy leak incurred by machine learning. However, FL still suffers from membership inference attacks (MIA) or data reconstruction attacks (DRA). In particular, an attacker can extract the information from local datasets by constructing DRA, which cannot be effectively throttled by existing techniques, e.g., Differential Privacy (DP).

In this paper, we aim to ensure a strong privacy guarantee for FL under DRA. We prove that reconstruction errors under DRA are constrained by the information acquired by an attacker, which means that constraining the transmitted information can effectively throttle DRA. To quantify the information leakage incurred by FL, we establish a channel model, which depends on the upper bound of joint mutual information between the local dataset and multiple transmitted parameters. Moreover, the channel model indicates that the transmitted information can be constrained through data space operation, which can improve training efficiency and the model accuracy under constrained information. According to the channel model, we propose algorithms to constrain the information transmitted in a single round of local training. With a limited number of training rounds, the algorithms ensure that the total amount of transmitted information is limited. Furthermore, our channel model can be applied to various privacy-enhancing techniques (such as DP) to enhance privacy guarantees against DRA. Extensive experiments with real-world datasets validate the effectiveness of our methods.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) [43, 61, 64, 65] is a new form of machine learning (ML), which protects privacy by transmitting gradients or parameters to avoid sharing raw data. Specifically, the parameters form a communication channel between the server and each client, so the server gets information from local datasets via such channels. Based on the Data Processing Inequality (DPI) [15], communication by parameters, which is a deterministic mapping of local data, instead of raw data, reduces the risk of data privacy. However, recent studies reveal that the parameter channel of FL still leaks privacy. For example, multiple literature indicates that adversaries can conduct membership inference attacks (MIA) with uploaded model parameters [50, 46, 44, 42, 13, 10], which breaks the anonymity of data privacy. Moreover, adversaries can completely steal training data by data reconstruction attacks (DRA) [28, 66, 11, 24, 12], resulting in serious privacy issues in FL.

In order to enhance privacy protection for FL, dimension reduction [37, 48, 54] or differential privacy (DP) [3, 35, 36] are widely adopted approaches. However, dimension reduction lacks theoretical guarantees of the defense ability against DRA, so it cannot flexibly configure defense capabilities according to different privacy requirements. DP’s privacy protection can provide theoretical guarantees (e.g., the privacy budget ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon) for MIA attacks [7, 22]. It aims to guarantee that changing any data point will not significantly affect the output distribution of a system. This goal is different from the one in defending against DRA, which focuses on preventing the attacker from reconstructing the whole distribution of the local dataset. Thus DP still cannot defend against DRA attacks [14, 39, 26, 7, 22]. For instance, in DP-SGD, algorithms with identical privacy budget but different training hyper-parameters (e.g., different batch size B𝐵B) cannot guarantee the same success rate for DRA [26]. Moreover, quantifying information leakage is the basis for defending against DRA attacks. Previous technique like Quantitative Information Flow (QIF)111QIF focuses on a special security concern, namely the probability of guessing a secret in one try [5, 53]. This security concern is different from the one in DRA, where DRA focuses on reconstructing the whole distribution of local data. [5] quantifies information leak under a white-box and time-invariant setting[49]. It requires the knowledge of the correlation between the distributions of inputs and outputs, which cannot hold in FL systems.

It is difficult to defend against DRA attacks in FL due to the following challenges. (i) the black-box model. For DNN-based models, the correlation between the input distribution and output distribution is extremely complex, and we cannot obtain the exact mapping function between the two distributions, making theoretical analysis impossible. (ii) the high-dimensional parameter space. Traditional mathematical tools (e.g., eigen-decomposition) cannot process high-dimensional parameter spaces on the scale of thousands of millions due to the requirements for large-scale storage and high-performance computing. (iii) the time-variant system. During the training process, constant parameter updates change the model at each step, leading to a time-variant system in FL. The time-variant system, which changes the output distributions accordingly, leads to dynamic information leakage, requiring continuously changing quantifications.

To address the above challenges, we develop a theoretical framework based on mutual information (MI)222Mutual information I​(X;Y)𝐼𝑋𝑌I(X;Y) [16, 51, 29] represents the uncertainty decrement of X𝑋X when we observe Y𝑌Y. to evaluate privacy leakage caused by DRA in FL, and design methods to constrain information leakage to defend against DRA attacks. Specifically, we demonstrate that the lower bound of mean squared error (MSE), which serves as an indicator of DRA’s precision in reconstruction (i.e., the smaller MSE means the higher precision for the attacker), is determined by the amount of acquired information, i.e., the MI between the local dataset and the shared parameters. Thus, MI can be utilized as the indicator for quantifying the information leakage in FL. Then we build a channel model to analyze information leaks under the black-box setting of FL. Through our proposed channel model, we find that the transmitted information (i.e., the information leakage) is decided by two factors: the channel capacity C𝐶C, which represents the maximal ability to transmit information in a single training round; and the optimization rounds n𝑛n, which is correlated to the information accumulation. For example, if the channel capacity is bounded by a threshold κ𝜅\kappa, and the number of optimization rounds is less than n𝑛n, then the total amount of information leakage is less than n⋅κ⋅𝑛𝜅n\cdot\kappa. Furthermore, our channel model can analyze various privacy-enhancing methods in defending against DRA, including DP, gradient compression, and utilizing large batch size.

Based on the channel model, we utilize DPI to transform the operations (e.g., eigen-decomposition and adding noise) of constraining channel capacity from the parameter space to the data space. This transformation significantly improves the training efficiency and the model accuracy of the high dimensional and time-variant model under constrained information leakage. Specifically, our protecting goal is to decide the covariance matrix for the added noise according to a given data distribution 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}}, which ensures privacy protection by constraining the reconstruction error above a certain threshold. Compared to conventional protection techniques, which directly deal with parameters after gradient mapping, constraining in the data space has two distinct advantages: firstly, it makes the computational complexity independent of the optimization rounds n𝑛n and the model’s dimensionality dmsubscript𝑑𝑚d_{m}, reducing it from 𝒪​(n⋅dm)𝒪⋅𝑛subscript𝑑𝑚\mathcal{O}(n\cdot d_{m}) to 𝒪​(dD)𝒪subscript𝑑𝐷\mathcal{O}(d_{D}), where dDsubscript𝑑𝐷d_{D} denotes the dimensionality of the data and dD≪dmmuch-less-thansubscript𝑑𝐷subscript𝑑𝑚d_{D}\ll d_{m}. Secondly, data space preserves the correlations between data attributes, hence we can leverage the prior knowledge of relative importance to implement stronger safeguards for the critical attributes, which enhances the capability to balance the utility and the privacy.

Finally, according to the theoretical results, we propose three implementations for constraining the channel capacity. These implementations incorporate different prior knowledge in defending against DRA, which can be employed to flexibly balance the utility and the privacy.

In summary, the contributions of our paper are as follows:

  • •

    We demonstrate that the amount of transmitted information decides the lower bound of the reconstruction error for DRA attacks.

  • •

    We establish a channel model to quantify the information leakage of the black-box model in FL, which can be applied to analyze various privacy-enhancing methods for defending against DRA.

  • •

    We theoretically constrain the transmitted information through the operation in data space instead of parameter space for the first time and demonstrate that it significantly improves the training efficiency and the model accuracy under constrained information leakage.

  • •

    By incorporating different prior knowledge, we propose three implementations to constrain channel capacity, which can be utilized to flexibly balance the utility and the privacy.

  • •

    Extensive experiments demonstrate that the newly proposed methods effectively enhance the safety, efficiency, and flexibility of FL.

2 Background and Preliminary

This paper studies the FL problem based on information theory. Specifically, in the FL scenario, the server and clients communicate by sending model parameters. Even without direct data sharing, the MI between shared parameters and the local dataset grows accordingly, which enhances the ability for attackers to conduct DRA attacks. For clarity purposes, Tab. 1 lists major notations used in the paper, and we will describe the remaining variables when they are utilized.

2.1 Federated Learning

Regarding FL, a specific client, namely the victim, receives the initial parameter 𝑾1subscript𝑾1{\bm{W}}_{1} from the server in a specific communication round and conducts the optimization process with the victim’s dataset as

𝑾t+1←𝑾t−η⋅∇𝑾F​(𝑾t;𝑫),t=1,⋯,E,formulae-sequence←subscript𝑾𝑡1subscript𝑾𝑡⋅𝜂subscript∇𝑾𝐹subscript𝑾𝑡𝑫𝑡1⋯𝐸{\bm{W}}_{t+1}\leftarrow{\bm{W}}_{t}-\eta\cdot\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}}_{t};{\bm{D}}),\;t=1,\,\cdots,\,E, (1)

where E𝐸E is the number of local steps. Then the victim sends 𝑾E+1subscript𝑾𝐸1{\bm{W}}_{E+1} back to the server. If we rewrite 𝑾1subscript𝑾1{\bm{W}}_{1} and 𝑾E+1subscript𝑾𝐸1{\bm{W}}_{E+1} as 𝑾isubscript𝑾𝑖{\bm{W}}_{i} and 𝑾osubscript𝑾𝑜{\bm{W}}_{o} respectively, the two parameters form a communication channel for information transmission (as illustrated in Fig. 2), and the local optimization process defined in Eq. (1) loads information from the dataset to the communication channel. Finally, the server collects the parameters from different clients (including the victim) for aggregation as

𝑾i=𝒜​(𝑾o;𝑽).subscript𝑾𝑖𝒜subscript𝑾𝑜𝑽{\bm{W}}_{i}={\mathcal{A}}({\bm{W}}_{o};{\bm{V}}). (2)

2.2 Information Theory

Differential Entropy. The differential entropy of a random variable 𝑿𝑿{\bm{X}} is defined as follows

h​(𝑿)=−∫𝑿f​(𝒙)​log⁡f​(𝒙)​𝑑𝒙,ℎ𝑿subscript𝑿𝑓𝒙𝑓𝒙differential-d𝒙h({\bm{X}})=-\int_{{\bm{X}}}f({\bm{x}})\log f({\bm{x}})\,d{\bm{x}}, (3)

which is utilized to describe the degree of random uncertainty. For a dataset with high information entropy, i.e., a dataset with plentiful information, it is difficult for an attacker to conduct DRA attacks. While for the dataset with low information entropy, the opposite is true.

However, calculating the differential entropy by Eq. (3) is infeasible in practice since we cannot obtain the distribution function of the target variable. Therefore, we use the maximum entropy distribution to analyze the worst-case scenario. Specifically, with 𝔼​[𝑿]=𝝁𝔼delimited-[]𝑿𝝁{\mathbb{E}}[{\bm{X}}]={\bm{\mu}} and C​o​v​(𝑿)=𝚺𝐶𝑜𝑣𝑿𝚺Cov({\bm{X}})={\bm{\Sigma}}, the maximum entropy distribution is the Gaussian distribution, i.e., h​(𝑿)≤h​(𝒩​(𝝁,𝚺))ℎ𝑿ℎ𝒩𝝁𝚺h({\bm{X}})\leq h({\mathcal{N}}({\bm{\mu}},{\bm{\Sigma}})).

Mutual Information. For two random variables 𝑿𝑿{\bm{X}} and 𝒀𝒀{\bm{Y}}, the mutual information between them is

I​(𝑿;𝒀)=h​(𝑿)−h​(𝑿|𝒀)=h​(𝒀)−h​(𝒀|𝑿).𝐼𝑿𝒀ℎ𝑿ℎconditional𝑿𝒀ℎ𝒀ℎconditional𝒀𝑿I({\bm{X}};{\bm{Y}})=h({\bm{X}})-h({\bm{X}}|{\bm{Y}})=h({\bm{Y}})-h({\bm{Y}}|{\bm{X}}). (4)

Specifically, the mutual information I​(𝑿;𝒀)𝐼𝑿𝒀I({\bm{X}};{\bm{Y}}) is a symmetric function, which describes the random uncertainty decrement of 𝑿𝑿{\bm{X}} when we observe 𝒀𝒀{\bm{Y}}, and vice versa.

Specifically, in this paper, we utilize I​(𝑫;𝑾i,𝑾o)𝐼𝑫subscript𝑾𝑖subscript𝑾𝑜I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}_{i},{\bm{W}}_{o}) to quantify the information leakage in FL. The intuition is that when an attacker observes the communication parameters of a victim, the random uncertainty of the victim’s local dataset will decrease, which implies the attacker can extract information from the victim’s local dataset to achieve more precise DRA.

Channel Capacity. The key factor in describing a communication channel is channel capacity. In information theory, traditional channel capacity is defined by the maximum MI between the sending variable 𝑿𝑿{\bm{X}} and the receiving variable 𝒀𝒀{\bm{Y}}, i.e., C=maxp​(𝒙)⁡I​(𝑿;𝒀)𝐶subscript𝑝𝒙𝐼𝑿𝒀C=\max_{p({\bm{x}})}\;I({\bm{X}};{\bm{Y}}), which is the maximum information that we can send by information coding.

In this work, the sending variable is 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}}, while the receiving variable is 𝑾osubscript𝑾𝑜{\bm{W}}_{o}, which is decided by the variables 𝑾isubscript𝑾𝑖{\bm{W}}_{i} and 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}} according to Eq. (1), hence the channel capacity can be formalized as C=maxp​(𝒘o)⁡I​(𝑫;𝑾o|𝑾i)𝐶subscript𝑝subscript𝒘𝑜𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscript𝑾𝑜subscript𝑾𝑖C=\max_{p({\bm{w}}_{o})}\;I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}_{o}|{\bm{W}}_{i}), which is the upper bound of the transmitted information.

The reasons for choosing MI to measure the information leakage. Prior research like QIF and g-leakage utilizes min-entropy [5, 53] to measure the information leakage, which can only work in a white-box and time-invariant system [49]. However, FL is a black-box (e.g., deep neural networks) and time-variant (e.g., parameter updating in each round) system. Hence, these techniques are not applicable. Moreover, min-entropy is unsuitable for modeling the attack against FL, e.g., DRA. The min-entropy focuses on measuring the uncertainty of guessing the most likely output of random sources [23, 30], which is more related to cryptographic systems. However, in DRA, the attacker’s target is to reconstruct the whole data distribution based on the victim’s sharing parameters, instead of guessing a most likely data point. Therefore, the precision of DRA attacks depends on the difference between two distributions, which must take all data of the distributions into consideration. In this scenario, the Shannon entropy, i.e., MI, which is based on the expectation metric, can accurately measure the correlation between the whole distributions, thus is more suitable for analyzing the information leakage issue under DRA. Therefore, we choose MI to measure the information leakage in FL.

3 Key Observation and Method Overview

3.1 Key Observation

Regarding FL, different clients jointly optimize the model by passing parameters to the server instead of raw data. Since the parameters are the mapping of the original data, the attacker can still reconstruct the private data from the parameters, thereby stealing privacy. Correspondingly, the client can preserve privacy by perturbing the transmitted parameters. Therefore, we build a channel model to calculate the privacy data contained in parameters. Moreover, based on the quantitative results, the privacy data in parameters can be flexibly adjusted to meet various privacy requirements.

In this section, we establish a formal correlation between the transmitted information, i.e., the MI, and the reconstruction error of DRA by the following theorem.

Theorem 1 (Lower bound for reconstruction error).

For any random variable 𝐃𝐃{\bm{D}}, 𝐃∈ℝd𝐃superscriptℝ𝑑{\bm{D}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and 𝐖𝐖{\bm{W}}, 𝐖∈ℝm𝐖superscriptℝ𝑚{\bm{W}}\in\mathbb{R}^{m}, we have

𝔼​[‖𝑫−𝑫^​(𝑾)‖2/d]≥e2​h​(𝑫)/d2​π​e​e−2​I​(𝑫;𝑾)/d,𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝑫^𝑫𝑾2𝑑superscript𝑒2ℎ𝑫𝑑2𝜋𝑒superscript𝑒2𝐼𝑫𝑾𝑑\mathbb{E}[\|{\bm{D}}-\hat{{\bm{D}}}({\bm{W}})\|^{2}/d]\geq\frac{e^{2h({\bm{D}})/d}}{2\pi e}e^{-2I({\bm{D}};\;{\bm{W}})/d}, (5)

where 𝐃^​(𝐖)^𝐃𝐖\hat{{\bm{D}}}({\bm{W}}) is an estimator of 𝐃𝐃{\bm{D}} constructed by 𝐖𝐖{\bm{W}}.

Specifically, Eq. (5) denotes the lower bound of MSE in DRA, which represents the optimal error for data reconstruction. In the FL scenario, we denote 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}} as the target data distribution and 𝑾𝑾{\bm{W}} as the shared parameter. Therefore h​(𝑫)ℎ𝑫h({\bm{D}}) is the entropy of the target data distribution, which is a constant during machine learning. Moreover, the lower bound is negatively correlated to MI, i.e., I​(𝑫;𝑾)𝐼𝑫𝑾I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}), which indicates that if 𝑾𝑾{\bm{W}} contains more information of target data 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}}, i.e., a larger I​(𝑫;𝑾)𝐼𝑫𝑾I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}), the attacker can achieve a more precise reconstruction of 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}}. Consequently, large I​(𝑫;𝑾)𝐼𝑫𝑾I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}) exacerbates the privacy issue.

In FL, MI increases as the number of optimization rounds increases, thereby enhancing the precision of DRA. Therefore, constraining the overall MI in FL is the way to restrict the precision of DRA. To this end, we build a channel model to measure the increase of MI in Sec. 4, and propose three implementation methods to limit MI within a certain threshold.

3.2 Method Overview

In this study, we develop techniques to enhance FL’s capability of privacy protection, in particular, defending against DRA. Normally, FL transmits information from the local dataset to the server by model parameters, i.e., the parameter channel. The transmitted information can be employed by an attacker to conduct various attacks. Hence, the objective of privacy protection is to constrain the amount of transmitted information. Specifically, for DRA, the reconstruction error is lower bounded by a function of MI (Thm. 1), which indicates that a smaller MI leads to a larger reconstruction error. Therefore, our technique is devoted to limiting the reconstruction ability by constraining the total MI in FL.

Threat Model. In this work, we focus on privacy leaks incurred by DRA in FL. Specifically, the attacker aims to reconstruct the data distribution 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}} of a specific client (i.e., the victim) via parameters shared by the victim. We assume that the attacker can get the transmitted parameters by the victim (i.e., 𝑾isubscript𝑾𝑖{\bm{W}}_{i} and 𝑾osubscript𝑾𝑜{\bm{W}}_{o}). Then the attacker can reconstruct a data distribution 𝑫^​(𝑾i,𝑾o)^𝑫subscript𝑾𝑖subscript𝑾𝑜\hat{{\bm{D}}}({\bm{W}}_{i},{\bm{W}}_{o}) to approximate the target data distribution 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}} (Appendix A explains the details of DRA).

Our goal is to constrain the private data that the attacker can obtain according to the transmitted parameters in FL. Therefore, the attacker’s ability to construct the DRA attack is limited.

Controlled parameter channel. As illustrated in Fig. 1, to restrict the transmitted information, we transform the noiseless parameter 𝑾osubscript𝑾𝑜{\bm{W}}_{o} to a noisy Gaussian channel by adding Gaussian noise 𝒩​(𝟎,𝚺)𝒩0𝚺{\mathcal{N}}(\bm{0},{\bm{\Sigma}}) to it. Based on the theorem of Gaussian channel in information theory [15], the noisy Gaussian channel has limited capability for information transmission, which is the channel capacity. Thus, with the eigenvalues of 𝑾osubscript𝑾𝑜{\bm{W}}_{o}, we derive a formula f​(𝚺)𝑓𝚺f({\bm{\Sigma}}) to characterize the channel capacity of the Gaussian channel by the maximum entropy distribution. Finally, we solve the equation f​(𝚺)=κ𝑓𝚺𝜅f({\bm{\Sigma}})=\kappa to decide 𝚺𝚺{\bm{\Sigma}} for constraining the transmitted information within a threshold κ𝜅\kappa. We will explain how the controlled parameter channel constrains transmitted information in Sec. 4 and Sec. 5.1.

Constraining channel capacity in the data space. To overcome the efficiency issue caused by the high dimensional and time-variant model in FL, we theoretically transform operations of constraining channel capacity from the parameter space to the data space. Specifically, the information contained in the resulting parameter is decided by the input data, thus constraining channel capacity can be achieved by restricting the information contained in the input data. Moreover, this transformation significantly improves the training efficiency and the model accuracy under constrained information leakage. We will explain the transformation in Sec. 5.2.

Theoretically, when an attacker observes 𝑾isubscript𝑾𝑖{\bm{W}}_{i} and 𝑾osubscript𝑾𝑜{\bm{W}}_{o}, the random uncertainty of the local data 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}} decreases, which means the attacker gets more information to conduct DRA attacks, leading to more precise reconstruction. The amount of random uncertainty reduction Δ​IΔ𝐼\Delta I (i.e., information leakage) in a round can be formalized as

Δ​I=I​(𝑫;𝑾i,𝑾o)−I​(𝑫;𝑾i)=I​(𝑫;𝑾o|𝑾i),Δ𝐼𝐼𝑫subscript𝑾𝑖subscript𝑾𝑜𝐼𝑫subscript𝑾𝑖𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscript𝑾𝑜subscript𝑾𝑖\Delta I=I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}_{i},{\bm{W}}_{o})-I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}_{i})=I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}_{o}|{\bm{W}}_{i}),

which means the attacker gets Δ​IΔ𝐼\Delta I information from 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}} (as illustrated in Fig. 2). Moreover, this privacy leak occurs in each optimization round, which results in an increase in MI and consistently increases the risk of privacy.

As aforementioned, for defending against DRA, our technique constructs a controlled parameter channel by limiting Δ​IΔ𝐼\Delta I to less than a threshold κ𝜅\kappa for all optimization rounds. Then together with the bounded optimization rounds n𝑛n, we provide n⋅κ⋅𝑛𝜅n\cdot\kappa guarantee for the total information leakage, thereby constraining the attack precision of DRA.

4 Channel Model of the Information Leakage

In this section, we formalize the problem of FL into a communication process based on information theory and then unfold the recurrent communication process into a time-dependent Markov Chain. Finally, we build a channel model to calculate the MI according to the unfolded communication process.

4.1 Accumulation of Mutual Information

As illustrated in Fig. 2, in the FL scenario, a specific client, i.e., the victim, communicates with the server through a logic channel: the parameters 𝑾isubscript𝑾𝑖{\bm{W}}_{i} and 𝑾osubscript𝑾𝑜{\bm{W}}_{o}. Specifically, There are three different information flows: the ingress flow, i.e., the received parameter 𝑾isubscript𝑾𝑖{\bm{W}}_{i}, which determines the background knowledge possessed by the server (i.e., the attacker); the egress flow, which is the information contained in the sharing parameter 𝑾osubscript𝑾𝑜{\bm{W}}_{o}; and the internal flow, i.e., local optimization process, which loads the information contained in the local dataset to the egress flow. Particularly, due to privacy requests, the victim only communicates with the server by 𝑾isubscript𝑾𝑖{\bm{W}}_{i} and 𝑾osubscript𝑾𝑜{\bm{W}}_{o}.

The information leakage of the communication channel depends on the MI increment when the server observes 𝑾osubscript𝑾𝑜{\bm{W}}_{o}. Thus, it can be formalized as

I​(𝑫;𝑾i,𝑾o)=I​(𝑫;𝑾i)⏟Prior+I​(𝑫;𝑾o|𝑾i)⏟Information Leakage (Δ​I).𝐼𝑫subscript𝑾𝑖subscript𝑾𝑜subscript⏟𝐼𝑫subscript𝑾𝑖Priorsubscript⏟𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscript𝑾𝑜subscript𝑾𝑖Information Leakage (ΔI)I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}_{i},{\bm{W}}_{o})=\underbrace{I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}_{i})}_{\text{Prior}}+\underbrace{I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}_{o}|{\bm{W}}_{i})}_{\text{Information Leakage ($\Delta I$)}}. (6)

Eq. (6) is an immediate result according to the chain rule of MI. It indicates that the MI between 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}} and the joint distribution (𝑾i,𝑾o)subscript𝑾𝑖subscript𝑾𝑜({\bm{W}}_{i},{\bm{W}}_{o}) can be divided into two parts: the prior knowledge and the information leakage Δ​IΔ𝐼\Delta I. In the rest of this paper, we will utilize I​(𝑫;𝑾o|𝑾i)𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscript𝑾𝑜subscript𝑾𝑖I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}_{o}|{\bm{W}}_{i}) instead of Δ​IΔ𝐼\Delta I for more comprehensible analysis.

However, 𝑾isubscript𝑾𝑖{\bm{W}}_{i} and 𝑾osubscript𝑾𝑜{\bm{W}}_{o} are joint distributions of different rounds, which contain multiple local learning processes. Hence, connecting Eq. (6) to the internal flow is difficult. To resolve this issue, we unfold the recurrent process to a time-dependent Markov chain. As illustrated in Fig. 2, there is only one local optimization process within a round from 𝑾i(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i} to 𝑾i(t+1)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡1𝑖{\bm{W}}^{(t+1)}_{i}, hence we can analyze MI increment at round t𝑡t.

Specifically, according to Eq. (1) and Eq. (2), the relationship between 𝑾i(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i} and 𝑾o(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o} in Fig. 2 is

𝑾o(t)=𝑾i(t)−η⋅∇𝑾F​(𝑾i(t);𝑫),subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖⋅𝜂subscript∇𝑾𝐹subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖𝑫{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}={\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}-\eta\cdot\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i};{\bm{D}}), (7)

which represents the local learning process with SGD. While for 𝑾o(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o} and 𝑾i(t+1)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡1𝑖{\bm{W}}^{(t+1)}_{i}, the relationship is

𝑾i(t+1)=𝒜(t)​(𝑾o(t);𝑽(t)),subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡1𝑖superscript𝒜𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜superscript𝑽𝑡{\bm{W}}^{(t+1)}_{i}={\mathcal{A}}^{(t)}({\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o};{\bm{V}}^{(t)}), (8)

where 𝑽(t)superscript𝑽𝑡{\bm{V}}^{(t)} are the variables uploaded by clients other than the victim.

Then based on the unfolded process, we transform the MI in Eq. (6) to the joint mutual information as

I​(𝑫;𝑾i(0),𝑾o(0),⋯,𝑾i(n))𝐼𝑫subscriptsuperscript𝑾0𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑾0𝑜⋯subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑛𝑖\displaystyle I({\bm{D}};\;{\bm{W}}^{(0)}_{i},{\bm{W}}^{(0)}_{o},\cdots,{\bm{W}}^{(n)}_{i})
=\displaystyle= ∑t=0nI​(𝑫;𝑾i(t)|𝑾o(t−1),𝑾i(t−1),⋯,𝑾o(0),𝑾i(0))superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑛𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡1𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡1𝑖⋯subscriptsuperscript𝑾0𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾0𝑖\displaystyle\textstyle\sum_{t=0}^{n}I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}|{\bm{W}}^{(t-1)}_{o},{\bm{W}}^{(t-1)}_{i},\cdots,{\bm{W}}^{(0)}_{o},{\bm{W}}^{(0)}_{i})
+∑t=0n−1I​(𝑫;𝑾o(t)|𝑾i(t),𝑾o(t−1),⋯,𝑾o(0),𝑾i(0))superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑛1𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡1𝑜⋯subscriptsuperscript𝑾0𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾0𝑖\displaystyle+\textstyle\sum_{t=0}^{n-1}I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i},{\bm{W}}^{(t-1)}_{o},\cdots,{\bm{W}}^{(0)}_{o},{\bm{W}}^{(0)}_{i})
=\displaystyle= ∑t=0n−1I​(𝑫;𝑾o(t)|𝑾i(t))⏟Γc​l​i​e​n​t+∑t=0n−1I​(𝑫;𝑾i(t+1)|𝑾o(t))⏟Γs​e​r​v​e​rsubscript⏟superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑛1𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖subscriptΓ𝑐𝑙𝑖𝑒𝑛𝑡subscript⏟superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑛1𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡1𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptΓ𝑠𝑒𝑟𝑣𝑒𝑟\displaystyle\underbrace{\textstyle\sum_{t=0}^{n-1}I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i})}_{\Gamma_{client}}+\underbrace{\textstyle\sum_{t=0}^{n-1}I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}^{(t+1)}_{i}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o})}_{\Gamma_{server}}
+I​(𝑫;𝑾i(0))⏟Prior,subscript⏟𝐼𝑫subscriptsuperscript𝑾0𝑖Prior\displaystyle+\underbrace{I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}^{(0)}_{i})}_{\text{Prior}}, (9)

where the first equality depends on the chain rule of MI and the last equality is an immediate consequence of the Markov property of the learning process.

Specifically, Eq. (4.1) indicates that the overall MI is comprised of three parts: the prior, Γs​e​r​v​e​rsubscriptΓ𝑠𝑒𝑟𝑣𝑒𝑟\Gamma_{server}, and Γc​l​i​e​n​tsubscriptΓ𝑐𝑙𝑖𝑒𝑛𝑡\Gamma_{client}.

4.2 Analysis of Mutual Information

Regarding Eq. (4.1), the information can be divided into three parts: the prior, Γs​e​r​v​e​rsubscriptΓ𝑠𝑒𝑟𝑣𝑒𝑟\Gamma_{server}, and Γc​l​i​e​n​tsubscriptΓ𝑐𝑙𝑖𝑒𝑛𝑡\Gamma_{client}. The prior knowledge I​(𝑫;𝑾i(0))𝐼𝑫subscriptsuperscript𝑾0𝑖I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}^{(0)}_{i}) is decided by the background knowledge of the attacker before the learning process.

For Γs​e​r​v​e​rsubscriptΓ𝑠𝑒𝑟𝑣𝑒𝑟\Gamma_{server}, it represents the aggregation process on the server, hence it cannot be controlled by the local learning process. On the contrary, it can be exploited by an attacker. Without loss of generality, we focus on the general term I​(𝑫;𝑾i(t+1)|𝑾o(t))𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡1𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}^{(t+1)}_{i}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}), t∈{0,⋯,n−1}𝑡0⋯𝑛1t\in\{0,\cdots,n-1\}, which is the information increment on the server. Based on the relationship between the MI and the entropy, we rewrite it as

I​(𝑫;𝑾i(t+1)|𝑾o(t))𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡1𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜\displaystyle\;I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}^{(t+1)}_{i}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o})
=\displaystyle= h​(𝑾i(t+1)|𝑾o(t))−h​(𝑾i(t+1)|𝑫,𝑾o(t))ℎconditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡1𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜ℎconditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡1𝑖𝑫subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜\displaystyle\;h({\bm{W}}^{(t+1)}_{i}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o})-h({\bm{W}}^{(t+1)}_{i}|{\bm{D}},{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o})
=\displaystyle= h​(𝒜(t)​(𝑾o(t);𝑽(t))|𝑾o(t))−h​(𝒜(t)​(𝑾o(t);𝑽(t))|𝑫,𝑾o(t)),ℎconditionalsuperscript𝒜𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜superscript𝑽𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜ℎconditionalsuperscript𝒜𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜superscript𝑽𝑡𝑫subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜\displaystyle\;h({\mathcal{A}}^{(t)}({\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o};{\bm{V}}^{(t)})|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o})-h({\mathcal{A}}^{(t)}({\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o};{\bm{V}}^{(t)})|{\bm{D}},{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}),

the last equality is a substitution according to Eq. (8). The formula indicates that I​(𝑫;𝑾i(t+1)|𝑾o(t))𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡1𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}^{(t+1)}_{i}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}) is decided by 𝑽(t)superscript𝑽𝑡{\bm{V}}^{(t)}, which are variables independent of local learning process.

Specifically, if 𝑽(t)superscript𝑽𝑡{\bm{V}}^{(t)} is independent of 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}}, then 𝑫→𝑾o(t)→𝑾i(t+1)→𝑫subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜→subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡1𝑖{\bm{D}}\rightarrow{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}\rightarrow{\bm{W}}^{(t+1)}_{i} forms a Markov chain. Therefore, given the observation of 𝑾o(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}, 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}} is conditional independent of 𝑾i(t+1)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡1𝑖{\bm{W}}^{(t+1)}_{i}, i.e., I​(𝑫;𝑾i(t+1)|𝑾o(t))=0𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡1𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜0I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}^{(t+1)}_{i}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o})=0. In this situation, Γs​e​r​v​e​r=0subscriptΓ𝑠𝑒𝑟𝑣𝑒𝑟0\Gamma_{server}=0, which means the server (i.e., the attacker) cannot affect DRA attacks. On the contrary, if 𝑽(t)superscript𝑽𝑡{\bm{V}}^{(t)} has the information of 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}} that is independent of 𝑾o(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}, i.e., the attacker can get auxiliary information other than the local learning process, the mutual information I​(𝑫;𝑾i(t+1)|𝑾o(t))>0𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡1𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜0I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}^{(t+1)}_{i}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o})>0, which increases the risk of information leakage for the rest communication rounds when T≥t+1𝑇𝑡1T\geq t+1. In this situation, the server (i.e., the attacker) can increase the risk of privacy by utilizing the information collected by means other than FL.

However, the analysis of Γs​e​r​v​e​rsubscriptΓ𝑠𝑒𝑟𝑣𝑒𝑟\Gamma_{server} is beyond the protection of the local learning process in FL, since Γs​e​r​v​e​rsubscriptΓ𝑠𝑒𝑟𝑣𝑒𝑟\Gamma_{server} is related to the auxiliary information for the attacker to conduct the DRA attack. Particularly, our target is to bound Γc​l​i​e​n​tsubscriptΓ𝑐𝑙𝑖𝑒𝑛𝑡\Gamma_{client}, which is the information leakage of the local learning process in FL. Sec. 5 indicates that regardless of Γs​e​r​v​e​r>0subscriptΓ𝑠𝑒𝑟𝑣𝑒𝑟0\Gamma_{server}>0 or not, Γc​l​i​e​n​tsubscriptΓ𝑐𝑙𝑖𝑒𝑛𝑡\Gamma_{client} is constrained by our methods.

Finally, we put emphasis on Γc​l​i​e​n​tsubscriptΓ𝑐𝑙𝑖𝑒𝑛𝑡\Gamma_{client}, the most important part that is correlated to information leakage of the local learning process in FL. Similarly, we focus on the general term of Γc​l​i​e​n​tsubscriptΓ𝑐𝑙𝑖𝑒𝑛𝑡\Gamma_{client}, i.e., I​(𝑫;𝑾o(t)|𝑾i(t))𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}), which is the MI increment at round t𝑡t, then we have

I​(𝑫;𝑾o(t)|𝑾i(t))=h​(𝑾o(t)|𝑾i(t))−h​(𝑾o(t)|𝑫,𝑾i(t)).𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖ℎconditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖ℎconditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜𝑫subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i})=h({\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i})-h({\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{D}},{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}). (10)

Based on Eq (7), if 𝑾i(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i} is observed, 𝑾o(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o} is decided by a deterministic function of 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}}, which has a finite entropy. Moreover, if 𝑾i(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i} and 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}} are both observed, 𝑾o(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o} is deterministic, thereby h​(𝑾o(t)|𝑫,𝑾i(t))→−∞→ℎconditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜𝑫subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖h({\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{D}},{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i})\to-\infty. The result is reasonable since the volume of a constant’s support set333The volume of support set for a random variable 𝑿𝑿{\bm{X}} is 2h​(𝑿)superscript2ℎ𝑿2^{h({\bm{X}})} [15]. goes to 00, i.e., 2−∞=0superscript202^{-\infty}=0. In this case, I​(𝑫;𝑾o(t)|𝑾i(t))→+∞→𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i})\to+\infty, which means a noiseless channel results in unlimited risk of privacy leaks.

To limit the information leakage, we add a Gaussian noise to 𝑾o(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}, which transforms Eq. (10) to a noisy egress flow. Specifically, we turn to analyze

𝑾~o(t)=𝑾o(t)+𝝃,subscriptsuperscript~𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜𝝃\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}={\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}+\bm{\xi}, (11)

where 𝝃∼𝒩​(𝟎,𝚺)similar-to𝝃𝒩0𝚺\bm{\xi}\sim{\mathcal{N}}(\bm{0},{\bm{\Sigma}}), and 𝑾o(t)=lim𝚺→𝟎𝑾~o(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜subscript→𝚺0subscriptsuperscript~𝑾𝑡𝑜{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}=\lim_{{\bm{\Sigma}}\to\bm{0}}\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}. Then the property of 𝑾~o(t)subscriptsuperscript~𝑾𝑡𝑜\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o} is implied by following lemma.

Lemma 1 (Maximum entropy distribution).

Let 𝐗𝐗{\bm{X}} be a continuous random vector with 𝔼​[𝐗]=𝛍𝐗𝔼delimited-[]𝐗subscript𝛍𝐗{\mathbb{E}}[{\bm{X}}]={\bm{\mu}}_{{\bm{X}}}, C​o​v​(𝐗)=𝚺𝐗𝐶𝑜𝑣𝐗subscript𝚺𝐗Cov({\bm{X}})={\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{X}}}. Let 𝐘∼𝒩​(𝛍𝐘,𝚺𝐘)similar-to𝐘𝒩subscript𝛍𝐘subscript𝚺𝐘{\bm{Y}}\sim{\mathcal{N}}({\bm{\mu}}_{{\bm{Y}}},{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{Y}}}) be a Gaussian random variable that is independent with 𝐗𝐗{\bm{X}}, then h​(𝐗+𝐘)ℎ𝐗𝐘h({\bm{X}}+{\bm{Y}}) achieves its maximum when 𝐗∼𝒩​(𝛍𝐗,𝚺𝐗)similar-to𝐗𝒩subscript𝛍𝐗subscript𝚺𝐗{\bm{X}}\sim{\mathcal{N}}({\bm{\mu}}_{{\bm{X}}},{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{X}}}).

To analyze the noisy egress flow after transformation, we rewrite Eq. (10) as

I​(𝑫;𝑾~o(t)|𝑾i(t))=h​(𝑾o(t)+𝝃|𝑾i(t))−h​(𝑾o(t)+𝝃|𝑫,𝑾i(t)).𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖ℎsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜conditional𝝃subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖ℎsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜conditional𝝃𝑫subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i})=h({\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}+\bm{\xi}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i})-h({\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}+\bm{\xi}|{\bm{D}},{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}). (12)

As 𝝃𝝃\bm{\xi} is a Gaussian variable, Lemma 1 implies that the first term on the right-hand side of Eq. (12), i.e., h​(𝑾o(t)+𝝃|𝑾i(t))ℎsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜conditional𝝃subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖h({\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}+\bm{\xi}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}), is upper bounded by the entropy of the Gaussian distribution. Moreover, when 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}} and 𝑾i(t)superscriptsubscript𝑾𝑖𝑡{\bm{W}}_{i}^{(t)} are both observed, 𝑾o(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o} is a constant, which means the only randomness of 𝑾~o(t)=𝑾o(t)+𝝃subscriptsuperscript~𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜𝝃\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}={\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}+\bm{\xi} comes from 𝝃𝝃\bm{\xi}, thus the second term on the right-hand side of Eq. (12) is h​(𝒩​(𝟎,𝚺))ℎ𝒩0𝚺h({\mathcal{N}}(\bm{0},{\bm{\Sigma}})). Let 𝔼​[𝑾o(t)]=𝝁𝑾𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜subscript𝝁𝑾{\mathbb{E}}[{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}]={\bm{\mu}}_{{\bm{W}}} and C​o​v​(𝑾o(t))=𝚺𝑾𝐶𝑜𝑣subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜subscript𝚺𝑾Cov({\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o})={\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{W}}}, we have the upper bound of Eq. (12) as

I​(𝑫;𝑾~o(t)|𝑾i(t))≤h​(𝒩​(𝝁𝑾,𝚺𝑾+𝚺))−h​(𝒩​(𝟎,𝚺)).𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖ℎ𝒩subscript𝝁𝑾subscript𝚺𝑾𝚺ℎ𝒩0𝚺I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i})\leq h({\mathcal{N}}({\bm{\mu}}_{{\bm{W}}},{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{W}}}+{\bm{\Sigma}}))-h({\mathcal{N}}(\bm{0},{\bm{\Sigma}})). (13)

In practice, the distribution of 𝑾o(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o} is extremely complex and time-variant, so we utilize upper bound (13) to limit the information leakage. The important parts of Eq. (13) are the covariance matrixes of 𝑾o(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o} and 𝝃𝝃\bm{\xi}. Moreover, Sec. 5 indicates that regardless of 𝚺𝑾subscript𝚺𝑾{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{W}}}, we can restrict I​(𝑫;𝑾~o(t)|𝑾i(t))≤κ𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖𝜅I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i})\leq\kappa, ∀κ>0for-all𝜅0\forall\,\kappa>0, by deciding 𝚺𝚺{\bm{\Sigma}}.

Finally, for multiple local updates, the scenario is slightly different. We denote the number of local steps in one communication round as E𝐸E, and the total number of local steps for all communication rounds as n𝑛n, where n𝑛n is divisible into E𝐸E. These notations imply that the number of communications is T=nE𝑇𝑛𝐸T=\frac{n}{E}. Then the issue can be transformed to the one-step case by a time-dependent aggregation method as

𝑾i(t)={𝒜(t)​(𝑾o(t−1);𝑽(t−1)),if ​E|t𝑾o(t−1),otherwise.subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖casessuperscript𝒜𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡1𝑜superscript𝑽𝑡1conditionalif 𝐸𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡1𝑜otherwise\displaystyle{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}=\begin{cases}{\mathcal{A}}^{(t)}({\bm{W}}^{(t-1)}_{o};\;{\bm{V}}^{(t-1)}),&\mbox{if }E\,|\,t\\ {\bm{W}}^{(t-1)}_{o},&\mbox{otherwise}.\end{cases} (14)

Where E|tconditional𝐸𝑡E\,|\,t represents we make aggregation on the server every E𝐸E steps. If we set E=n𝐸𝑛E=n, the FL problem reduces to classical ML without collaboration.

Based on the former analysis, the new aggregation rule only changes Γs​e​r​v​e​rsubscriptΓ𝑠𝑒𝑟𝑣𝑒𝑟\Gamma_{server} in Eq. (4.1), while Γc​l​i​e​n​tsubscriptΓ𝑐𝑙𝑖𝑒𝑛𝑡\Gamma_{client} remains the same. Hence, the privacy analysis for the local optimization process is identical to classical ML. Therefore, our analysis of Γc​l​i​e​n​tsubscriptΓ𝑐𝑙𝑖𝑒𝑛𝑡\Gamma_{client} will focus on classical ML in the remainder of this paper.

5 Controlled Parameter Channel

Based on the former analysis, the important part of defending against DRA is I​(𝑫;𝑾~o(t)|𝑾i(t))𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}), which represents the MI increment at round t𝑡t. The key parameters to restrict the MI increment are 𝚺𝑾subscript𝚺𝑾{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{W}}} and 𝚺𝚺{\bm{\Sigma}}. In this section, we first propose a method for deciding 𝚺𝚺{\bm{\Sigma}} that ensures I​(𝑫;𝑾~o(t)|𝑾i(t))≤κ𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖𝜅I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i})\leq\kappa. Then, we transform the operations for constraining MI from the parameter space to the data space and propose three implementation methods for constraining the channel capacity. Finally, we analyze existing techniques with our theoretical results in defending against DRA.

5.1 Controlled Channel Capacity

Channel capacity is the maximum ability to transmit information within a single round, i.e., max⁡I​(𝑫;𝑾~o(t)|𝑾i(t))𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖\max\;I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}), which is the key parameter for constraining the information leakage.

To constrain the channel capacity, we have Thm 2.

Theorem 2 (Channel capacity).

Let 𝐖~o(t)=𝐖o(t)+σ⋅𝛏subscriptsuperscript~𝐖𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝐖𝑡𝑜⋅𝜎𝛏\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}={\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}+\sqrt{\sigma}\cdot\bm{\xi}, where σ≥0𝜎0\sigma\geq 0 and 𝛏∼𝒩​(𝟎,𝐈)similar-to𝛏𝒩0𝐈\bm{\xi}\sim{\mathcal{N}}(\bm{0},{\mathbf{I}}), if 𝛍(t)superscript𝛍𝑡{\bm{\mu}}^{(t)} and 𝚺(t)superscript𝚺𝑡{\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)} are the mean vector and covariance matrix of 𝐖o(t)subscriptsuperscript𝐖𝑡𝑜{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o} when 𝐖i(t)subscriptsuperscript𝐖𝑡𝑖{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i} is observed, we have I​(𝐃;𝐖~o(t)|𝐖i(t))≤f(t)​(σ)𝐼𝐃conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~𝐖𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝐖𝑡𝑖superscript𝑓𝑡𝜎I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i})\leq f^{(t)}(\sigma), where

f(t)​(σ):=12​∑i=1dln⁡λi(t)+σσ,σ∈(0,+∞).formulae-sequenceassignsuperscript𝑓𝑡𝜎12superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑡𝑖𝜎𝜎𝜎0f^{(t)}(\sigma):=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{d}\ln\frac{\lambda^{(t)}_{i}+\sigma}{\sigma},\;\sigma\in(0,\;+\infty). (15)

where λi(t)subscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑡𝑖\lambda^{(t)}_{i} is the i-th eigenvalue of the covariance matrix 𝚺(t)superscript𝚺𝑡{\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)} and d𝑑d represents the dimension of 𝐖o(t)subscriptsuperscript𝐖𝑡𝑜{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}.

Based on Lemma 1, I​(𝑫,𝑾~o(t)|𝑾i(t))𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖I({\bm{D}},\;\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}) achieves its maximum f(t)​(σ)superscript𝑓𝑡𝜎f^{(t)}(\sigma) when 𝑾o(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o} conforms to the Gaussian distribution. According to the Central Limit Theorem, if we use mini-batch SGD, the distribution of 𝑾o(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o} converges to the Gaussian distribution, which means upper bound (15) becomes tighter when we utilize larger batch size for local training.

Regarding Γc​l​i​e​n​tsubscriptΓ𝑐𝑙𝑖𝑒𝑛𝑡\Gamma_{client}, if we denote C(t)=f(t)​(σ(t))superscript𝐶𝑡superscript𝑓𝑡superscript𝜎𝑡C^{(t)}=f^{(t)}(\sigma^{(t)}), where σ(t)superscript𝜎𝑡\sigma^{(t)} represents σ𝜎\sigma at time t𝑡t, we have I​(𝑫;𝑾~o(t)|𝑾i(t))≤C(t)𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖superscript𝐶𝑡I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i})\leq C^{(t)}, which indicates 𝑾i(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i} and 𝑾~o(t)subscriptsuperscript~𝑾𝑡𝑜\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o} form a communication channel with channel capacity C(t)superscript𝐶𝑡C^{(t)}.

Specifically, according to Eq. (15), C(t)superscript𝐶𝑡C^{(t)} is decided by two components: {λi(t)}i=1dsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑡𝑖𝑑𝑖1\{\lambda^{(t)}_{i}\}^{d}_{i=1} and σ(t)superscript𝜎𝑡\sigma^{(t)}. First, {λi(t)}i=1dsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑡𝑖𝑑𝑖1\{\lambda^{(t)}_{i}\}^{d}_{i=1} represent the eigenvalues of 𝚺(t)superscript𝚺𝑡{\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)}. Based on Eq. (7), 𝑾o(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o} is related to 𝑾i(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}, which is the parameter received from the server. Therefore, the server (i.e., the attacker) can craft 𝑾i(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i} to get more information from the local dataset (as displayed in Fig. 5).

Second, σ(t)superscript𝜎𝑡\sigma^{(t)} is related to the added noise. Based on the monotonicity of C(t)=f(t)​(σ(t))superscript𝐶𝑡superscript𝑓𝑡superscript𝜎𝑡C^{(t)}=f^{(t)}(\sigma^{(t)}), we conclude that for any 𝑾i(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}, there exists an unique σ(t)superscript𝜎𝑡\sigma^{(t)} that satisfies f(t)​(σ(t))=κsuperscript𝑓𝑡superscript𝜎𝑡𝜅f^{(t)}(\sigma^{(t)})=\kappa, where κ≥0𝜅0\kappa\geq 0 is a certain threshold.

If we denote λi(t)=λ(t)subscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑡𝑖superscript𝜆𝑡\lambda^{(t)}_{i}=\lambda^{(t)}, i∈{1,⋯,d}𝑖1⋯𝑑i\in\{1,\cdots,d\}, we have C(t)=d2​ln⁡(λ(t)+σ(t)σ(t))superscript𝐶𝑡𝑑2superscript𝜆𝑡superscript𝜎𝑡superscript𝜎𝑡C^{(t)}=\frac{d}{2}\ln(\frac{\lambda^{(t)}+\sigma^{(t)}}{\sigma^{(t)}}). In this scenario, the channel capacity can be displayed as Fig. 5. Specifically, the channel capacity is an increasing function of λ(t)superscript𝜆𝑡\lambda^{(t)} and a decreasing function of σ(t)superscript𝜎𝑡\sigma^{(t)}. Moreover, it is worth noting that even the server can change the channel capacity by crafting 𝑾i(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}, the victim can constrain the transmitted information within κ𝜅\kappa by solving f(t)​(σ(t))=κsuperscript𝑓𝑡superscript𝜎𝑡𝜅f^{(t)}(\sigma^{(t)})=\kappa after receiving 𝑾i(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}, which decides the added noise σ(t)superscript𝜎𝑡\sigma^{(t)}.

5.2 Limiting Channel Capacity in Data Space

For a controlled parameter channel, our target is to constrain the transmitted information at round t𝑡t, i.e., I​(𝑫;𝑾~o(t)|𝑾i(t))𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}). Based on Thm. 2, there are two steps for solving the equation C(t)=κsuperscript𝐶𝑡𝜅C^{(t)}=\kappa in the parameter space: the eigen-decomposition of 𝚺(t)superscript𝚺𝑡{\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)} and solving the high order equation with corresponding eigenvalues. Whereas, 𝑾o(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o} is a high-dimensional and time-variant parameter, which leads to an extremely large number of calculations. Hence, the implementation of the aforementioned method in the parameter space is computationally expensive.

Regarding 𝑾o(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o} in Fig. 2, when 𝑾i(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i} is observed, it is conditional independent with the previous parameters 𝑾∗(s)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑠{\bm{W}}^{(s)}_{*}, ∀s<tfor-all𝑠𝑡\forall s<t, and all of the previous local learning processes. Therefore, if 𝑾i(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i} is observed, 𝑾o(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o} is purely decided by the local learning process at round t𝑡t, i.e., 𝑫→𝑾o(t)|𝑾i(t)→𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖{\bm{D}}\rightarrow{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}. Then based on these properties, we design a random function M​(⋅)𝑀⋅M(\cdot) to map the raw data 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}} to the noisy data 𝑫~~𝑫\widetilde{{\bm{D}}}, and then utilize the noisy data for the local training, i.e., 𝑾~o(t)=𝑾i(t)−η⋅∇𝑾F​(𝑾i(t);𝑫~)subscriptsuperscript~𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖⋅𝜂subscript∇𝑾𝐹subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖~𝑫\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}={\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}-\eta\cdot\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i};\widetilde{{\bm{D}}}).

If we use the random function M​(⋅)𝑀⋅M(\cdot) before the local learning process, the variables form a Markov Chain, i.e., 𝑫→𝑫~→𝑾o(t)|𝑾i(t)→𝑫~𝑫→conditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖{\bm{D}}\rightarrow\widetilde{{\bm{D}}}\rightarrow{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}. According to the DPI [15], we have

I​(𝑫;𝑾o(t)|𝑾i(t))≤I​(𝑫;𝑫~|𝑾i(t))=I​(𝑫;𝑫~),𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖𝐼𝑫conditional~𝑫subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖𝐼𝑫~𝑫I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i})\leq I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{D}}}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i})=I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{D}}}), (16)

where the last equality results from the independence between M​(⋅)𝑀⋅M(\cdot) and 𝑾i(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}. Therefore, we can bound I​(𝑫;𝑫~)𝐼𝑫~𝑫I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{D}}}) so as to restrict I​(𝑫;𝑾o(t)|𝑾i(t))𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖I({\bm{D}};{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{o}|{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i}). Moreover, bounding I​(𝑫;𝑫~)𝐼𝑫~𝑫I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{D}}}) enables us to limit the channel capacity in the data space. Specifically, we use 𝑫~=M​(𝑫)=𝑫+𝝃~𝑫𝑀𝑫𝑫𝝃\widetilde{{\bm{D}}}=M({\bm{D}})={\bm{D}}+{\bm{\xi}} as the random function, where 𝝃∼𝒩​(𝟎,𝚺𝝃)similar-to𝝃𝒩0subscript𝚺𝝃{\bm{\xi}}\sim{\mathcal{N}}(\bm{0},{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{\xi}}}), and the key parameter is 𝚺𝝃subscript𝚺𝝃{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{\xi}}}.

The rationale of constraining transmitted information in data space. In addition to the upper bound derived by DPI, we can explain the rationale of constraining in data space by Taylor’s expansion for a more comprehensible analysis. Specifically, if we use a Gaussian noise in the data space to constrain the information leakage, we can expand the gradient mapping as follows

∇𝑾F​(𝑾;𝑫+𝝃)subscript∇𝑾𝐹𝑾𝑫𝝃\displaystyle\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}};{\bm{D}}+\bm{\xi}) =\displaystyle= ∇𝑾F​(𝑾;𝑫)+∇𝑫∇𝑾⁡F​(𝑾;𝑫)T⋅𝝃subscript∇𝑾𝐹𝑾𝑫⋅subscript∇𝑫subscript∇𝑾𝐹superscript𝑾𝑫T𝝃\displaystyle\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}};{\bm{D}})+\nabla_{{\bm{D}}}\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}};{\bm{D}})^{\text{T}}\cdot\bm{\xi}
+O​(‖𝝃‖2).𝑂superscriptnorm𝝃2\displaystyle+O(\|\bm{\xi}\|^{2}). (17)

Eq. (5.2) indicates that constraining the transmitted information in the data space is equivalent to adding an adaptive noise ∇𝑫∇𝑾⁡F​(𝑾;𝑫)T⋅𝝃⋅subscript∇𝑫subscript∇𝑾𝐹superscript𝑾𝑫T𝝃\nabla_{{\bm{D}}}\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}};{\bm{D}})^{\text{T}}\cdot\bm{\xi} to the parameter.

Moreover, the coefficient ∇𝑫∇𝑾⁡F​(𝑾;𝑫)subscript∇𝑫subscript∇𝑾𝐹𝑾𝑫\nabla_{{\bm{D}}}\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}};{\bm{D}})is the variation of ∇𝑾F​(𝑾;𝑫)subscript∇𝑾𝐹𝑾𝑫\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}};{\bm{D}}). If ∇𝑾F​(𝑾;𝑫)subscript∇𝑾𝐹𝑾𝑫\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}};{\bm{D}}) changes significantly according to the data 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}}, which means the gradient has a high distinction degree with regard to the data, i.e., the gradient leaks more information, the large coefficient will provide strong privacy protection. Otherwise, the small coefficient leads to better utility without violating the privacy requirements.

Additionally, Fig. 5 provides a toy example for understanding the rationale of constraining in the data space. Specifically, we set D∼𝒩​(−1,1)similar-to𝐷𝒩11D\sim\mathcal{N}(-1,1) and our target is to decide the model W𝑊W that minimizes F​(W;D)=W2​D𝐹𝑊𝐷superscript𝑊2𝐷F(W;D)=W^{2}D through gradient descent. Particularly, we require the information leakage to be less than 111, i.e., C(t)=1superscript𝐶𝑡1C^{(t)}=1. As illustrated in Fig. 5, when we use the method in the parameter space to limit C(t)=1superscript𝐶𝑡1C^{(t)}=1 at W(t)=2superscript𝑊𝑡2W^{(t)}=2, i.e., adding the noise ξ∼𝒩​(0,16e2−1)similar-to𝜉𝒩016superscript𝑒21\xi\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\frac{16}{e^{2}-1}) to the gradient ∇WF​(W;D)=2​W​Dsubscript∇𝑊𝐹𝑊𝐷2𝑊𝐷\nabla_{W}F(W;D)=2\,WD, the resulting noise cannot guarantee C(t+1)=1superscript𝐶𝑡11C^{(t+1)}=1 at next round W(t+1)=6superscript𝑊𝑡16W^{(t+1)}=6 (we set the learning rate to 111), which implies that we need to recalculate the covariance matrix for the noise at each round. On the contrary, constraining in the data space (adding the noise ξ∼𝒩​(0,1e2−1)similar-to𝜉𝒩01superscript𝑒21\xi\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\frac{1}{e^{2}-1}) to the data D𝐷D) results in an adaptive noise to guarantee C(t)=1superscript𝐶𝑡1C^{(t)}=1 for all t𝑡t regardless of W(t)superscript𝑊𝑡W^{(t)}, leading to the O​(1)𝑂1O(1) time-complexity for achieving the privacy requirement.

By incorporating different prior knowledge, we propose three implementation methods for deciding 𝚺𝝃subscript𝚺𝝃{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{\xi}}}.

Natural Channel. For Natural Channel, the relative importance of different data attributes is naturally decided by the data itself. Specifically, based on Thm. 2, with substituting 𝑫~~𝑫\widetilde{{\bm{D}}} for 𝑾~o(t)subscriptsuperscript~𝑾𝑡𝑜\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}, we have

I​(𝑫;𝑫~)≤f​(σ)=12​∑i=1dln⁡λi+σσ,σ∈(0,+∞),formulae-sequence𝐼𝑫~𝑫𝑓𝜎12superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscript𝜆𝑖𝜎𝜎𝜎0I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{D}}})\leq f(\sigma)=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{d}\ln\frac{\lambda_{i}+\sigma}{\sigma},\;\sigma\in(0,\;+\infty), (18)

where λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} and d𝑑d represents the i𝑖i-th eigenvalue and the dimension of data 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}}, respectively. In this case, we chose 𝚺𝝃=σ​𝐈subscript𝚺𝝃𝜎𝐈{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{\xi}}}=\sigma{\mathbf{I}}. Moreover, f​(σ)𝑓𝜎f(\sigma) is a monotone function of σ𝜎\sigma, hence there is a unique σ𝜎\sigma satisfying f​(σ)=κ𝑓𝜎𝜅f(\sigma)=\kappa. Meanwhile, this σ𝜎\sigma guarantees I​(𝑫;𝑫~)≤f​(σ)=κ𝐼𝑫~𝑫𝑓𝜎𝜅I({\bm{D}};\widetilde{{\bm{D}}})\leq f(\sigma)=\kappa. Combining it with Eq. (16), we conclude that the information leakage at time t𝑡t is less than κ𝜅\kappa. However, f​(σ)=κ𝑓𝜎𝜅f(\sigma)=\kappa is a polynomial equation of order d𝑑d, hence we need to solve it with numerical methods (e.g., binary search). In summary, the process of Natural Channel is

  1. 1.

    Make the eigen-decomposition of 𝚺𝑫subscript𝚺𝑫{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{D}}}, which is the covariance matrix of data 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}}, to get Λ=d​i​a​g​(λ1,⋯,λd)Λ𝑑𝑖𝑎𝑔subscript𝜆1⋯subscript𝜆𝑑\Lambda=diag(\lambda_{1},\cdots,\lambda_{d})

  2. 2.

    Solve the equation f​(σ)=κ𝑓𝜎𝜅f(\sigma)=\kappa to get σ𝜎\sigma with binary search

  3. 3.

    Get 𝑫~=𝑫+𝝃~𝑫𝑫𝝃\widetilde{{\bm{D}}}={\bm{D}}+{\bm{\xi}}, where 𝝃∼𝒩​(𝟎,σ​𝐈)similar-to𝝃𝒩0𝜎𝐈{\bm{\xi}}\sim{\mathcal{N}}(\bm{0},\;\sigma{\mathbf{I}})

White Channel. In the method of the White Channel, we treat the relative importance of all attributes to be equal, which provides much stronger protection for the local dataset. For such a purpose, we add a constraint to Eq. (18) as

f​(𝚿)=12​∑i=1dln⁡λi+σiσi=κ𝑓𝚿12superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖𝜅\displaystyle f({\bm{\Psi}})=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{d}\ln\frac{\lambda_{i}+\sigma_{i}}{\sigma_{i}}=\kappa (19)
s.t.lnλi+σiσi=lnλj+σjσj,for 1≤i<j≤d,\displaystyle s.t.\quad\ln\frac{\lambda_{i}+\sigma_{i}}{\sigma_{i}}=\ln\frac{\lambda_{j}+\sigma_{j}}{\sigma_{j}},\;\text{for }1\leq i<j\leq d,

where 𝚿=diag⁡(σ1,⋯,σd)𝚿diagsubscript𝜎1⋯subscript𝜎𝑑{\bm{\Psi}}=\operatorname{\mathrm{diag}}(\sigma_{1},\cdots,\sigma_{d}) represents the eigenvalues of 𝚺𝝃subscript𝚺𝝃{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{\xi}}}. Then we can get σi=λiexp⁡(2​κ/d)−1subscript𝜎𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖2𝜅𝑑1\sigma_{i}=\frac{\lambda_{i}}{\exp(2\kappa/d)-1} by solving Eq (19). Finally, we need to transform 𝚿𝚿{\bm{\Psi}} back to 𝚺𝝃subscript𝚺𝝃{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{\xi}}}. According to Eq. (28) in the proof of Thm. 2, we have 𝚺𝑫=𝑸​𝚲​𝑸Tsubscript𝚺𝑫𝑸𝚲superscript𝑸𝑇{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{D}}}={\bm{Q}}\bm{\Lambda}{\bm{Q}}^{T}, where 𝑸𝑸{\bm{Q}} is an orthogonal matrix composed with the eigenvectors of 𝚺𝑫subscript𝚺𝑫{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{D}}}. Then with a similar process, we have 𝚺𝝃=𝑸​𝚿​𝑸Tsubscript𝚺𝝃𝑸𝚿superscript𝑸𝑇{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{\xi}}}={\bm{Q}}{\bm{\Psi}}{\bm{Q}}^{T}. Therefore, the typical process of the White Channel is

  3. 3.

    Get 𝚺𝝃=𝑸​𝚿​𝑸Tsubscript𝚺𝝃𝑸𝚿superscript𝑸𝑇{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{\xi}}}={\bm{Q}}{\bm{\Psi}}{\bm{Q}}^{T}
