    Get 𝑫~=𝑫+𝝃~𝑫𝑫𝝃\widetilde{{\bm{D}}}={\bm{D}}+{\bm{\xi}}, where 𝝃∼𝒩​(𝟎,𝚺𝝃)similar-to𝝃𝒩0subscript𝚺𝝃{\bm{\xi}}\sim{\mathcal{N}}(\bm{0},\;{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{\xi}}})

Personalized Channel. In practice, the relative importance of different attributes in data is different. For example, [62] claims that for online diagnosis, our target is to extract disease-relevant features but remove identity features from the facial images of patients, which means we add more noise to the identity features compared to the disease-relevant features. For analyzing the problem, we assume the relative importance of different dimensions is 𝜷=(β0,⋯,βd−1)T𝜷superscriptsubscript𝛽0⋯subscript𝛽𝑑1𝑇\bm{\beta}=(\beta_{0},\cdots,\beta_{d-1})^{T}, e.g., (height, weight)=(1, 2) represents the relative importance of the height to the weight is 1:2:121:2.

The relative importance decides the level of noise addition. In other words, if the attribute is more important, we add more noise to it for stronger protection. To utilize the prior knowledge 𝜷𝜷\bm{\beta}, we chose 𝚺𝝃=σ⋅diag⁡(𝜷)subscript𝚺𝝃⋅𝜎diag𝜷{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{\xi}}}=\sigma\cdot\operatorname{\mathrm{diag}}(\bm{\beta}). According to the proof of Thm. 2, σ𝜎\sigma is decided by

f​(σ)=ln​det[𝚺𝑫+σ⋅diag⁡(𝜷)]2​∑i=1dln⁡(σ⋅βi)=κ.𝑓𝜎delimited-[]subscript𝚺𝑫⋅𝜎diag𝜷2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑⋅𝜎subscript𝛽𝑖𝜅f(\sigma)=\frac{\ln\det[{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{D}}}+\sigma\cdot\operatorname{\mathrm{diag}}(\bm{\beta})]}{2\sum_{i=1}^{d}\ln(\sigma\cdot\beta_{i})}=\kappa. (20)

However, the intrinsic correlations of local data bring difficulties in solving Eq. (20), so we derive the following theorem for simplifying the calculation.

Theorem 3 (Upper bound of Personalized Channel.).

Let 𝚺=𝚺d−1𝚺subscript𝚺𝑑1{\bm{\Sigma}}={\bm{\Sigma}}_{d-1}, we can rewrite 𝚺𝚺{\bm{\Sigma}} as

𝚺i=subscript𝚺𝑖absent\displaystyle{\bm{\Sigma}}_{i}= (𝚺i−1𝝆i𝝆iTci,i),i∈{0,⋯,d−1},subscript𝚺𝑖1subscript𝝆𝑖superscriptsubscript𝝆𝑖Tsubscript𝑐𝑖𝑖𝑖0⋯𝑑1\displaystyle\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}{\bm{\Sigma}}_{i-1}&{\bm{\rho}}_{i}\\ {\bm{\rho}}_{i}^{\mathrm{T}}&c_{i,i}\end{array}\right),\;i\in\{0,\cdots,d-1\}, (23)

where d𝑑d represent the dimension of 𝚺𝚺{\bm{\Sigma}}, then we have

ln​det(𝚺+diag⁡(𝜷))≤min⁡[∑i=0d−1ln⁡(ci,i+βi),∑i=0d−1ln⁡(ui+ki)],𝚺diag𝜷superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑑1subscript𝑐𝑖𝑖subscript𝛽𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑑1subscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑘𝑖\displaystyle\ln\det({\bm{\Sigma}}+\operatorname{\mathrm{diag}}(\bm{\beta}))\leq\min[\sum_{i=0}^{d-1}\ln(c_{i,i}+\beta_{i}),\sum_{i=0}^{d-1}\ln(u_{i}+k_{i})],
ui=ci,i−𝝆iT​𝚺i−1−1​𝝆i,ki=βi+(𝚺i−1−1​𝝆i)T​diag⁡(𝜷)​(𝚺i−1−1​𝝆i).formulae-sequencesubscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑐𝑖𝑖superscriptsubscript𝝆𝑖Tsubscriptsuperscript𝚺1𝑖1subscript𝝆𝑖subscript𝑘𝑖subscript𝛽𝑖superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝚺1𝑖1subscript𝝆𝑖Tdiag𝜷subscriptsuperscript𝚺1𝑖1subscript𝝆𝑖\displaystyle u_{i}=c_{i,i}-{\bm{\rho}}_{i}^{\mathrm{T}}{\bm{\Sigma}}^{-1}_{i-1}{\bm{\rho}}_{i},\;k_{i}=\beta_{i}+({\bm{\Sigma}}^{-1}_{i-1}{\bm{\rho}}_{i})^{\mathrm{T}}\operatorname{\mathrm{diag}}(\bm{\beta})({\bm{\Sigma}}^{-1}_{i-1}{\bm{\rho}}_{i}).

Combining Thm. 3 with Eq. (20), we can get an upper bound of the channel capacity for the Personalized Channel

U​(σ)=min⁡[∑i=0d−1ln⁡(ci,i+σ​βi),∑i=0d−1ln⁡(ui+σ​ki)]2​∑i=1dln⁡(σ⋅βi).𝑈𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑑1subscript𝑐𝑖𝑖𝜎subscript𝛽𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑑1subscript𝑢𝑖𝜎subscript𝑘𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑⋅𝜎subscript𝛽𝑖U(\sigma)=\frac{\min[\sum_{i=0}^{d-1}\ln(c_{i,i}+\sigma\beta_{i}),\sum_{i=0}^{d-1}\ln(u_{i}+\sigma k_{i})]}{2\sum_{i=1}^{d}\ln(\sigma\cdot\beta_{i})}.

Moreover, U​(σ)𝑈𝜎U(\sigma) decouples 𝚺𝚺{\bm{\Sigma}} and diag⁡(𝜷)diag𝜷\operatorname{\mathrm{diag}}(\bm{\beta}),hence we can use a pre-processing to reduce the calculation of solving U​(σ)=κ𝑈𝜎𝜅U(\sigma)=\kappa. The process of the Personalized Channel is

  1. 1.

    Get uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} and kisubscript𝑘𝑖k_{i} according to Thm. (3)

  2. 2.

    Solve the equation U​(σ)=κ𝑈𝜎𝜅U(\sigma)=\kappa to get σ𝜎\sigma with binary search

  3. 3.

    Get 𝚺𝝃=σ⋅diag⁡(𝜷)subscript𝚺𝝃⋅𝜎diag𝜷{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{\xi}}}=\sigma\cdot\operatorname{\mathrm{diag}}(\bm{\beta})

  4. 4.

    Get 𝑫~=𝑫+𝝃~𝑫𝑫𝝃\widetilde{{\bm{D}}}={\bm{D}}+{\bm{\xi}}, where 𝝃∼𝒩​(𝟎,𝚺𝝃)similar-to𝝃𝒩0subscript𝚺𝝃{\bm{\xi}}\sim{\mathcal{N}}(\bm{0},\;{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{\xi}}})

Finally, we visualize 𝑫~~𝑫\widetilde{{\bm{D}}} of different implementations according to different channel capacities in Fig. 5. Moreover, we discuss the advantages and the disadvantages of different channel implementations in Appendix G.

Furthermore, constraining in the data space brings two advantages: first, compared to the parameter space, data space is white-box, low-dimensional, and time-invariant. Second, in the data space, the relative importance of attributes is preserved, which makes it easier to leverage prior knowledge.

Guidelines for noise injection. In summary, for defending against DRA, the important target is to restrict the transmitted information by noise addition. Here we provide guidelines for the noise injection:

  • •

    For privacy-enhancing techniques (e.g., DP and gradient compression) in FL, the reconstruction error for DRA is theoretically above a threshold (Thm. 1) when we restrict the transmitted information within κ𝜅\kappa. It can be achieved by solving f​(σ)=κ𝑓𝜎𝜅f(\sigma)=\kappa, where f​(σ)𝑓𝜎f(\sigma) is defined in Eq. (18). This equation decides the injection noise with corresponding statistics.

  • •

    For defending against DRA in FL, we can inject noise to the training data instead of transmitted parameters. This transformation can produce an adaptive noise, which reduces the computational complexity brought by the high dimensional and time-variant system in FL.

  • •

    For any pre-processing process such as embedding, we can get the same theoretical guarantee by substituting 𝚺e​m​b​e​d​d​i​n​gsubscript𝚺𝑒𝑚𝑏𝑒𝑑𝑑𝑖𝑛𝑔{\bm{\Sigma}}_{embedding} for 𝚺𝑫subscript𝚺𝑫{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{D}}} in Eq. (18), where 𝚺e​m​b​e​d​d​i​n​gsubscript𝚺𝑒𝑚𝑏𝑒𝑑𝑑𝑖𝑛𝑔{\bm{\Sigma}}_{embedding} and 𝚺𝑫subscript𝚺𝑫{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{D}}} are covariance matrixes calculated by embeddings and data, respectively.

  • •

    In our method, a larger batch size leads to a tighter upper bound and a stronger ability to defend against DRA.

5.3 Channel Capacity for Existing Methods

With Thm. 1 and Thm. 2, we can analyze existing methods for defending against DRA by the channel capacity C(t)superscript𝐶𝑡C^{(t)}.

Existing privacy-enhancing methods in FL can be divided into three categories: perturbation, compression, and utilizing large batch size. The method of perturbation is represented by DP. Moreover, we demonstrate that for defending against DRA, the methods of gradient compression and utilizing large batch size are equivalent to adding more noise for perturbation, and the intrinsic mechanism of them are restricting the transmitted information.

Perturbation. As a method with theoretical guarantee, DP focuses on the problem of protecting individual information. In this work, we consider the event-level DP [40, 36] because we focus on the privacy issue for a specific client (i.e., the victim). That is, whether the attacker can reconstruct the local dataset with the victim’s shared parameters. Specifically, the widely used DP technique in FL is the Gaussian mechanism, thus we analyze the Gaussian mechanism in this section. A typical process of the Gaussian mechanism for (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP consists of two stages: gradient clipping, which guarantees the sensitivity of the gradient is bounded; noise addition, which provides the (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP guarantee based on the bounded sensitivity. To analyze DP based on information theory, we have the following theorem.

Theorem 4 (Channel capacity for DP).

In FL, if the sensitivity of the gradient mapping is upper bounded by S𝑆S, i.e., ‖𝐠‖2≤Ssubscriptnorm𝐠2𝑆\|{\bm{g}}\|_{2}\leq S, the channel capacity of (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP, i.e., CD​Psubscript𝐶𝐷𝑃C_{DP}, is upper bounded by following formulas:

  1.  (1)

    CD​P≤B⋅S2σ,subscript𝐶𝐷𝑃⋅𝐵superscript𝑆2𝜎C_{DP}\leq\frac{B\cdot S^{2}}{\sigma},

  2.  (2)

    CD​P≤B⋅ϵ22​log⁡(1.25/δ),subscript𝐶𝐷𝑃⋅𝐵superscriptitalic-ϵ221.25𝛿C_{DP}\leq\frac{B\cdot\epsilon^{2}}{2\log(1.25/\delta)},

where B𝐵B represents the batch size and σ𝜎\sigma is the noise scale.

Compared to the conventional DP theorem, Thm. 4 indicates that batch size B𝐵B is a key factor of the defense ability to defend against DRA, which has been overlooked by prior literature. Specifically, increasing B𝐵B reduces DP’s ability to defend against DRA, which has been validated by experiments in Fig. 8 (the details are explained in Appendix D).

Compression. Another defense technique is compression, it intuitively focuses on reducing transmitted information by reducing the dimension of shared parameters. However, most of these methods lack theoretical guarantees.

Specifically, information is contained in each dimension of the gradient (i.e., the parameter), and the channel capacity decreases accordingly when we reduce the dimension of it. If we analyze the compression in the eigenspace, dimension reduction can be theoretically described by Thm. 2. Specifically, the total channel capacity is C(t)=12​∑i=1dln⁡λi(t)+σσsuperscript𝐶𝑡12superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑡𝑖𝜎𝜎C^{(t)}=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{d}\ln\frac{\lambda^{(t)}_{i}+\sigma}{\sigma}, and the general term 12​ln⁡λi(t)+σσ12subscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑡𝑖𝜎𝜎\frac{1}{2}\ln\frac{\lambda^{(t)}_{i}+\sigma}{\sigma} represents the channel capacity of the i𝑖i-th dimension. Compressing the i𝑖i-th dimension in the eigenspace, i.e., setting λi(t)=0subscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑡𝑖0\lambda^{(t)}_{i}=0, leads the channel capacity of i𝑖i-th dimension to be 00, thereby reducing the total channel capacity. As illustrated in Fig. 8, when we compress the gradient, i.e., setting eigenvalues to be 00, the results are equivalent to adding more noise for perturbation. As displayed in Fig. 8, we also conduct experiments to validate our theoretical result, the experiments indicate that the improvement of the defense ability becomes more significant when we compress the dimension with a larger eigenvalue (the details are explained in Appendix D). Due to the space limitation, we put the detailed analysis of compression in Appendix E.

Large Batch Size. Another defense strategy for privacy protection in FL is utilizing large batch size [66]. Our model can theoretically formalize this strategy. If we denote the batch size as B𝐵B, then the gradient in mini-batch SGD is 1B​∑i=1B∇𝑾F​(𝑾i(t);𝑫i)1𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐵subscript∇𝑾𝐹subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖subscript𝑫𝑖\frac{1}{B}\sum_{i=1}^{B}\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i};\;{\bm{D}}_{i}), where {𝑫i}i=1Bsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑫𝑖𝑖1𝐵\{{\bm{D}}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{B} represents the set of iid data points sampled from the dataset. The covariance matrix with large batch size is scaled by B𝐵B, i.e., 𝚺B(t)=1B​𝚺(t)subscriptsuperscript𝚺𝑡𝐵1𝐵superscript𝚺𝑡{\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)}_{B}=\frac{1}{B}{\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)}. Hence, with substituting 𝚺B(t)subscriptsuperscript𝚺𝑡𝐵{\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)}_{B} for 𝚺(t)superscript𝚺𝑡{\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)} in Thm. 2, we have

CB(t)=fB(t)​(σ):=12​∑i=1dln⁡(λi(t)/B+σ)σ.subscriptsuperscript𝐶𝑡𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑓𝐵𝑡𝜎assign12superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑡𝑖𝐵𝜎𝜎C^{(t)}_{B}=f_{B}^{(t)}(\sigma):=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{d}\ln\frac{(\lambda^{(t)}_{i}/B+\sigma)}{\sigma}. (24)

With the constant noise addition, C(t)superscript𝐶𝑡C^{(t)} is a decreasing function of B𝐵B, which means we can enhance the ability to defend against DRA by increasing B𝐵B. Fig. 8 experimentally validates this theory and we put the details of Fig. 8 in Appendix D due to the space limitation.

Guidelines for hyper-parameters. Finally, to improve existing defensive algorithms, we provide several guidelines for choosing the hyper-parameters in FL:

  • •

    A smaller batch size in DP algorithm is more effective to defend against DRA.

  • •

    Compressing the dimension with larger eigenvalue results in the stronger ability to defend against DRA.

  • •

    A larger batch size leads to a stronger defense ability to defend against DRA when we add a constant noise to the parameter during training.

6 Experiment

In this section, we conduct experiments with various models and datasets to validate our theories and compare our methods with other privacy-enhancing techniques. All experiments are performed upon a Supermicro SYS-420GP-TNR server with two Intel(R) Xeon(R) Gold 6348 CPUs (2×\times28 cores), Ubuntu 18.04.1, 10GB memory, and four NVIDIA A100 PCIe 80GB GPUs. Meanwhile, to eliminate the impact of randomness, each experiment is repeated 10 times.

6.1 Experimental Settings

Datasets. Dataset is a task-dependent factor, which means we cannot change the dataset when the training task is decided. In our experiments, we resize the data to 32*32 for comparison, and utilize four classical datasets, including CIFAR10 [31], CelebA [41], SVHN [47], and Fashion-MNIST [60].

Basic Models. In this work, we experiment with four classical model architectures, including LeNet [34], AlexNet [32], VGG16 [52], and ResNet10 [27]. Moreover, model architectures are task-independent, we can select architectures according to different goals, e.g., utility or privacy.

Attacks. We test our methods on two typical attacks in FL: MIA and DRA, the details of different attacks are as follows.

Membership Inference Attack. For MIA, we use the white-box attack [46, 39]. Meanwhile, we employ a partial knowledge attacker, which means the attacker can access to part of the training dataset. In this case, the attacker has much stronger background knowledge. Moreover, we use four inputs for attacking [39]: the samples’ ranked posteriors, classification loss, gradients of the last layer, and one-hot encoding of the true label. These inputs are fed into different neural networks to get different embeddings, then we concatenate all embeddings as the input of a 4-layer MLP to get the inference.

Data Reconstruction Attack. For DRA, we employ two representative attacks: model inversion attack and gradient inversion attack. For model inversion attack [20, 39], we first construct a dummy input with auxiliary information (i.e., the mean value of images that are not in the training dataset) as the input for the target model, then utilize different target labels to optimize the dummy input. We use Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 1e-2 for 600 iterations. Additionally, we employ the settings proposed by Geiping et al. [21] to investigate the defense ability for gradient inversion attacks.

Metric. We evaluate our design with various criteria, including the model utility, the defense capability against different attacks, the utility-privacy trade-offs, and the efficiency. To this end, we employ the following metrics for evaluation.

Test Accuracy. FL searches for an accurate model for classification, hence we use test accuracy as the metric for utility.

AUC. We use the attack AUC to measure the attack performance for MIA. It’s worth noting that a smaller AUC means a stronger defense capability.

MSE. We use MSE as the main metric for DRA since MSE is a general metric that indicates the convergence of random variables. That is, if the MSE of two random variables is 0, we conclude that they have identical distributions [58], which means a perfect reconstruction. Additionally, a large MSE means a stronger ability to defend against DRA. Moreover, we also utilize PSNR, SSIM, and Cosine Similarity to evaluate the defense ability, we put these results in Appendix F due to the space limitation. Specifically, for model inversion attacks, we calculate the metric between the reversed data and the center of the corresponding class for different classes. We use the median of all classes as the final metric. For gradient inversion attacks, we employ the mean value of the metric between the reconstructed data and the target data.

General Defense Capability (GDC). For evaluating the comprehensive defense capability, we use the improvements of the aforementioned attacks. Specifically, for MIA, we define the improvement as

I​M​PM​I​A=(A​U​Cw​i​t​h​o​u​t​_​d​e​f−A​U​C)/A​U​Cw​i​t​h​o​u​t​_​d​e​f.𝐼𝑀subscript𝑃𝑀𝐼𝐴𝐴𝑈subscript𝐶𝑤𝑖𝑡ℎ𝑜𝑢𝑡_𝑑𝑒𝑓𝐴𝑈𝐶𝐴𝑈subscript𝐶𝑤𝑖𝑡ℎ𝑜𝑢𝑡_𝑑𝑒𝑓IMP_{MIA}=({AUC}_{without\_def}-{AUC})/{AUC}_{without\_def}.

While the improvement for DRA is

I​M​PD​R​A=(1M​S​Ew​i​t​h​o​u​t​_​d​e​f−1M​S​E)/1M​S​Ew​i​t​h​o​u​t​_​d​e​f.𝐼𝑀subscript𝑃𝐷𝑅𝐴1𝑀𝑆subscript𝐸𝑤𝑖𝑡ℎ𝑜𝑢𝑡_𝑑𝑒𝑓1𝑀𝑆𝐸1𝑀𝑆subscript𝐸𝑤𝑖𝑡ℎ𝑜𝑢𝑡_𝑑𝑒𝑓IMP_{DRA}=(\frac{1}{MSE_{without\_def}}-\frac{1}{MSE})/\frac{1}{{MSE}_{without\_def}}.

Finally, we define general defense capability as

G​D​C=(I​M​PM​I​A+I​M​PD​R​A)/2,𝐺𝐷𝐶𝐼𝑀subscript𝑃𝑀𝐼𝐴𝐼𝑀subscript𝑃𝐷𝑅𝐴2GDC=(IMP_{MIA}+IMP_{DRA})/{2},

and a larger G​D​C𝐺𝐷𝐶GDC means a stronger defense capability.

Default parameter configuration. In our experiments, we mainly utilize natural channel to investigate the channel parameters. Specifically, we fix the optimization rounds as n=1×104𝑛1superscript104n=1\times 10^{4} and utilize κ𝜅\kappa in {50, 100, 200, 300} to investigate the effect of different channel capacities. Additionally, we fix κ=300𝜅300\kappa=300 and utilize T​o​t​a​l​I​n​f​o𝑇𝑜𝑡𝑎𝑙𝐼𝑛𝑓𝑜TotalInfo in {5×105,1×106,2×106,3×106}5superscript1051superscript1062superscript1063superscript106\{5\times 10^{5},1\times 10^{6},2\times 10^{6},3\times 10^{6}\} to investigate the effect of different n𝑛n, where n=⌊T​o​t​a​l​I​n​f​oκ⌋𝑛𝑇𝑜𝑡𝑎𝑙𝐼𝑛𝑓𝑜𝜅n=\lfloor\frac{TotalInfo}{\kappa}\rfloor and ⌊⋅⌋⋅\lfloor\cdot\rfloor is the floor function. We will explicitly explain it when we utilize different configurations.

6.2 The Effect of Controlled Channel

Impact of channel capacity (κ𝜅\kappa). κ𝜅\kappa represents the upper bound of information leakage in a single training round. As illustrated in Fig. 10, when we enhance the channel, i.e., increase κ𝜅\kappa, the accuracy increases accordingly regardless of the datasets and the model architectures, which means a wider channel leads to a better utility. However, the increasing utility is at the cost of reducing data privacy. Fig. 10 displays the corresponding defense capability against DRA. Specifically, for DRA attacks, the MSE decreases according to the increasing κ𝜅\kappa, which means the reconstructed data is closer to the target data. These results indicate that in the practical scenario, we can adjust channel capacity by κ𝜅\kappa to balance the utility and the privacy according to various requirements.

Moreover, we explicitly display the utility-privacy tradeoff in Fig. 11. Specifically, the utility increases with the increase of channel capacity κ𝜅\kappa, while the ability of privacy protection decreases with the increase of κ𝜅\kappa. These results are reasonable since channel capacity constrains the transmitted information, and the reconstruction error, i.e., the MSE, can be theoretically restricted when the transmitted information is limited based on Thm. 1. Meanwhile, more available information results in a more accurate model, indicating that the adjustable channel capacity can be utilized to balance the utility-privacy tradeoff.

Impact of optimization rounds (n𝑛n). Different from the channel capacity C𝐶C, the number of optimization rounds n𝑛n affects the parameter channel through another dimension: information accumulation. Similarly, the results in Fig. 14 and 14 imply that n𝑛n is another parameter to influence the utility and the defense ability of the controlled channel. Increasing n𝑛n results in obtaining more information from the local dataset, thereby enhancing the utility while reducing the defense ability.

Defense ability against gradient inversion attack. We randomly select 30 images from each dataset as the target data and evaluate the defense abilities to defend against gradient inversion attacks. As shown in Fig. 14, the MSE of data reconstruction consistently increases as we decrease the threshold κ𝜅\kappa, which means a smaller κ𝜅\kappa leads to a stronger ability to defend against DRA. The MSE of the White Channel and the Personalized Channel are larger than the Natural Channel, indicating that the other two methods provide stronger defense capability compared to the Natural Channel.

6.3 Comparing with Other Methods

In this section, we compare our methods with two classic perturbation mechanisms: DP-SGD [1] and DP-PSAC [59]. Specifically, DP-SGD first utilizes DP for ML and DP-PSAC is the state-of-art method to improve DP-SGD by adaptively clipping the gradients.

Utility-Privacy trade-off. We first compare our methods with DP-SGD and DP-PSAC in the utility-privacy plane. The plane is formed by two axes: the x𝑥x-axis represents GDC, which is the general ability for privacy protection. While the y𝑦y-axis represents the accuracy, which represents the utility. For all methods, we use the model of LeNet and fix the rounds as n=1×104𝑛1superscript104n=1\times 10^{4}. The results are displayed in Fig. 16. Specifically, in our methods, we use channel capacity in {50, 100, 200, 300} for the Natural Channel, and {500, 800, 1000, 1500} for the White Channel and the Personalized Channel. Additionally, we use 1:50 in 𝜷𝜷\bm{\beta} for the Personalized Channel to protect the attributes around the eyes (Appendix B indicates the details of 𝜷𝜷\bm{\beta}). For DP-SGD and DP-PSAC, we use the clipping bound S=1.0𝑆1.0S=1.0, δ=1×10−5𝛿1superscript105\delta=1\times 10^{-5} (δ=3×10−6𝛿3superscript106\delta=3\times 10^{-6} for CelebA), and the multiplier σ𝜎\sqrt{\sigma} in {0.8, 0.57, 0.46, 0.2066} (the corresponding privacy budget ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon for these DP training are {1.705, 5.120, 12.026, 331.668}, respectively) . According to Thm. 4, these σ𝜎\sigma result in channel capacities in {100, 200, 300, 1500} when we utilize B=64𝐵64B=64, which are identical to the channel capacities of our methods. As in Fig. 16, the Natural Channel achieves the best utility-privacy trade-off. The reason is that it utilizes the original importance to maintain the information in data attributes, and the constrained channel capacity ensures the ability to defend against DRA.

Comparison of the details in defense ability. To investigate the detailed defense ability of different methods, we decouple the defense capabilities to display them in the defense-defense plane. Specifically, x𝑥x-axis represents I​M​PD​R​A𝐼𝑀subscript𝑃𝐷𝑅𝐴IMP_{DRA} and y𝑦y-axis represents I​M​PM​I​A𝐼𝑀subscript𝑃𝑀𝐼𝐴IMP_{MIA}. As displayed in Fig. 16, DP specializes in defending against MIA but is weaker in defending against DRA, this is reasonable since DP focuses on protecting individual information. Compared to DP, our methods specialize in defending against DRA. Moreover, our methods achieve the best comprehensive defense capability for both attacks.

Efficiency of constraining in the data space. As displayed in Tab. 2, we compare the efficiency of our method with DP-SGD, which is a method that works in the parameter space. We use OPACUS 1.1.2 [63] for the implementation of DP-SGD. The results indicate that when we transform the operations to the data space, it significantly reduces the amount of calculation, i.e., the training time, especially when the dimension of the parameter increases.

7 Related Work

Differential Privacy. Differential Privacy [18] is an important technique for privacy protection. For the definition of differential privacy, Mironov [45] proposes to utilize Rényi divergence, which leads to compact and accurate privacy loss. Moreover, Abadi et al. [1] propose an empirical algorithm DP-SGD for applying DP to ML training, then multiple literature tries to improve the performance of DP-SGD [3, 6, 9, 59]. Most of them focus on the utility, trying to adaptively clip the gradients or add suitable perturbations. For the application of DP, Levy et al. [36] propose to protect user-level DP instead of ensuring the privacy of individual samples, which makes DP more reliable to FL. Truex et al. [55] present a protocol LDP-Fed to formally ensure data privacy in collecting local parameters with high precision. However, DP is still vulnerable to DRA, several researchers indicate that they can reconstruct the data without violating the requirements of DP [14, 17], implying that the algorithms are still vulnerable to DRA. Compared to DP, our work aims to defend against DRA based on information theory.

Limiting Mutual Information. Another related concept of privacy protection depends on MI. Several studies connect MI with DP by deriving the upper bound of MI for a distinct DP mechanism [8, 4, 16]. For privacy protection, Li et al. [37] propose to train a feature extractor that minimizes MI between the output features and the assigned label while maximizing the MI between output features and the original data. Similarly, Osia et al. [48] propose to train an extractor with the variational lower bound for MI estimation. Moreover, Hannun et al. [25] utilize Fisher Information to measure the information leakage, and the conclusions are consistent with our theories. Finally, we can also model FL based on information theory [2, 57], which measures the MI between different variables in FL. Compared to the former methods, our technique models the communication channel of FL directly based on information theory and utilizes its upper bound to derive practical methods for constraining the transmitted information, which leads to the strong ability to defend against DRA.

8 Discussion and Conclusion

Our method constrains the information leakage of the black-box model according to an upper bound derived by maximum entropy distribution (Lemma 1). We can tighten the upper bound by utilizing a large batch size or incorporating domain knowledge. Among them, utilizing large batch size for training causes the output distribution to be closer to a Gaussian distribution, while incorporating domain knowledge enables us to get more properties of the output distribution. If we get a tighter upper bound, the tradeoff between utility and privacy can be further improved.

In summary, as the reconstruction error of DRA is decided by the transmitted information, we build a channel model to measure the information leakage of the black-box model in FL. The model indicates that the amount of transmitted information is decided by the channel capacity C𝐶C and the number of optimization rounds n𝑛n. Guided by the model, we develop methods to constrain the channel capacity within a threshold κ𝜅\kappa. Combining it with the limited optimization rounds n𝑛n, the upper bound of the total transmitted information remains below n⋅κ⋅𝑛𝜅n\cdot\kappa, which ensures the ability to defend against DRA. Furthermore, we transform the operations of constraining channel capacity from the parameter space to the data space. The transformation significantly improves the training efficiency and the model accuracy under constrained information leakage. Finally, extensive experiments with real-world datasets validate the benefit of our methods.

Appendix A The detail explanation of DRA

For DRA in FL, the attacker aims to build a reconstruction 𝑫^​(𝑾i,𝑾o)^𝑫subscript𝑾𝑖subscript𝑾𝑜\hat{{\bm{D}}}({\bm{W}}_{i},{\bm{W}}_{o}) to approximate the data 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}}, where 𝑾isubscript𝑾𝑖{\bm{W}}_{i} and 𝑾osubscript𝑾𝑜{\bm{W}}_{o} are the transmitted parameters in FL. Moreover, if the MSE between 𝑫^​(𝑾i,𝑾o)^𝑫subscript𝑾𝑖subscript𝑾𝑜\hat{{\bm{D}}}({\bm{W}}_{i},{\bm{W}}_{o}) and 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}} achieves 00, i.e., 𝔼​‖𝑫^​(𝑾i,𝑾o)−𝑫‖2=0𝔼superscriptnorm^𝑫subscript𝑾𝑖subscript𝑾𝑜𝑫20\mathbb{E}\|\hat{{\bm{D}}}({\bm{W}}_{i},{\bm{W}}_{o})-{\bm{D}}\|^{2}=0, we conclude that 𝑫^​(𝑾i,𝑾o)^𝑫subscript𝑾𝑖subscript𝑾𝑜\hat{{\bm{D}}}({\bm{W}}_{i},{\bm{W}}_{o}) and 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}} have identical distributions [58].

Additionally, with the definition of 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}}, i.e., the random variable that follows the distribution of the local dataset, the MIA [10] can be viewed as inferring whether a particular data point belongs to the support set of 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}}.

Appendix B Details of the Prior Knowledge

For the Personalized Channel, the prior knowledge 𝜷𝜷\bm{\beta} used in Sec. 6 is a 32∗32∗c3232𝑐32*32*c tensor, where c𝑐c represents the number of image channel (e.g., c=1𝑐1c=1 for Fashion-MNIST dataset and c=3𝑐3c=3 for CIFAR-10 dataset, respectively). The number in 𝜷𝜷\bm{\beta} represents the coefficient for the added noise, which means we add more noise to the dimension if the coefficient of this dimension is larger. In these experiments, we employ position-based prior knowledge, which means the prior knowledge for all image channels are identical. Therefore, the important parameters are the numbers of one channel, which is a 32∗32323232*32 matrix (as displayed in Fig. 17).

Specifically, as we aim to protect the private information around eyes for the data in CelebA (as displayed in Fig. 5), we set the number of these positions (i.e., the sub-matrix with row 12 to 19 and column 8 to 23.) to be 505050, and set the rest number of the matrix to be 111. Therefore, this prior knowledge adds 505050 times noise to the chosen positions (i.e., the positions around the eyes) to provide stronger privacy protection for this area. Additionally, we also use this prior knowledge for other datasets, including Fashion-MNIST, CIFAR10, and SVHN.

Appendix C Proofs of Lemmas and Theorems

C.1 Proof of Theorem 1

Before the proof of Thm. 1, we have the following lemma.

Lemma 2.

For any d-dimensional semi-positive definite matrix 𝐀𝐀{\bm{A}}, i.e., 𝐀∈ℝd×d𝐀superscriptℝ𝑑𝑑{\bm{A}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d}, we have

det(𝑨)≤(tr⁡(𝑨)d)d.𝑨superscripttr𝑨𝑑𝑑\det({\bm{A}})\leq\left(\frac{\operatorname{\mathrm{tr}}({\bm{A}})}{d}\right)^{d}. (25)
Proof.

Since 𝑨𝑨{\bm{A}} is a semi-positive definite matrix, we have its eigen values, i.e., {λi}i=1dsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑑𝑖1\{\lambda_{i}\}^{d}_{i=1}, are non-negative. we can get

det(𝑨)=∏i=1dλi≤(∑i=1dλid)d=(tr⁡(𝑨)d)d,𝑨superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑑subscript𝜆𝑖superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscript𝜆𝑖𝑑𝑑superscripttr𝑨𝑑𝑑\displaystyle\det({\bm{A}})=\prod_{i=1}^{d}\lambda_{i}\leq\left(\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{d}\lambda_{i}}{d}\right)^{d}=\left(\frac{\operatorname{\mathrm{tr}}({\bm{A}})}{d}\right)^{d},

where the inequality depends on the AM-GM inequality. ∎

Then based on Lemma 2, we can prove Thm. 1.

Proof.

As C​o​v​(𝑫)𝐶𝑜𝑣𝑫Cov({\bm{D}}) is the covariance matrix of 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}}, we have

≤(4)​d2​log⁡(2​π​e)+d2​log⁡(𝔼​[𝔼​[‖𝑫−𝑫^​(𝑾)‖2|𝑾]]d)4𝑑22𝜋𝑒𝑑2𝔼delimited-[]𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptnorm𝑫^𝑫𝑾2𝑾𝑑\displaystyle\overset{(4)}{\leq}\frac{d}{2}\log(2\pi e)+\frac{d}{2}\log(\frac{\mathbb{E}[\mathbb{E}[\|{\bm{D}}-\hat{{\bm{D}}}({\bm{W}})\|^{2}|{\bm{W}}]]}{d})

where (1) is a consequence that with identical mean vector and covariance matrix, Gaussian distribution is the maximum entropy distribution. (2) depends on Lemma 2. The reason for (3) is that mean vector is the optimal estimator in terms of mean squared error, and (4) is a consequence of Jensen’s inequality. Hence,

where the last equality is a consequence of Eq. (4). ∎

C.2 Proof of Lemma 1

Proof.

Firstly, as 𝑿𝑿{\bm{X}} and 𝒀𝒀{\bm{Y}} are independent, then 𝔼​[𝑿+𝒀]=𝝁𝑿+𝝁𝒀𝔼delimited-[]𝑿𝒀subscript𝝁𝑿subscript𝝁𝒀{\mathbb{E}}[{\bm{X}}+{\bm{Y}}]={\bm{\mu}}_{{\bm{X}}}+{\bm{\mu}}_{{\bm{Y}}} and C​o​v​(𝑿+𝒀)=𝚺𝑿+𝚺𝒀𝐶𝑜𝑣𝑿𝒀subscript𝚺𝑿subscript𝚺𝒀Cov({\bm{X}}+{\bm{Y}})={\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{X}}}+{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{Y}}}.

Secondly, with a specific mean vector and covariance matrix, the maximum entropy distribution is Gaussian, which implies that h​(𝑿+𝒀)≤h​(𝒩​(𝝁𝑿+𝝁𝒀,𝚺𝑿+𝚺𝒀))ℎ𝑿𝒀ℎ𝒩subscript𝝁𝑿subscript𝝁𝒀subscript𝚺𝑿subscript𝚺𝒀h({\bm{X}}+{\bm{Y}})\leq h({\mathcal{N}}({\bm{\mu}}_{{\bm{X}}}+{\bm{\mu}}_{{\bm{Y}}},\;{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{X}}}+{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{Y}}})).

Finally, if 𝑿∼𝒩​(𝝁𝑿,𝚺𝑿)similar-to𝑿𝒩subscript𝝁𝑿subscript𝚺𝑿{\bm{X}}\sim{\mathcal{N}}({\bm{\mu}}_{{\bm{X}}},\;{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{X}}}), then 𝑿+𝒀∼𝒩​(𝝁𝑿+𝝁𝒀,𝚺𝑿+𝚺𝒀)similar-to𝑿𝒀𝒩subscript𝝁𝑿subscript𝝁𝒀subscript𝚺𝑿subscript𝚺𝒀{\bm{X}}+{\bm{Y}}\sim{\mathcal{N}}({\bm{\mu}}_{{\bm{X}}}+{\bm{\mu}}_{{\bm{Y}}},\;{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{X}}}+{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{Y}}}), which concludes the proof. ∎

C.3 Proof of Theorem 2

Proof.

According to the relationship between mutual information and differential entropy, we have

I​(𝑫,𝑾~o(t)|𝑾i(t))𝐼𝑫conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖\displaystyle\;I({\bm{D}},\;\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}\;|\;{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i})
=\displaystyle= h​(𝑾~o(t)|𝑾i(t))−h​(𝑾~o(t)|𝑫,𝑾i(t))ℎconditionalsubscriptsuperscript~𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖ℎconditionalsubscriptsuperscript~𝑾𝑡𝑜𝑫subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖\displaystyle\;h(\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}\;|\;{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i})-h(\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}\;|\;{\bm{D}},\;{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i})
=\displaystyle= h​(𝑾~o(t)|𝑾i(t))−h​(𝒩​(𝟎,σ⋅𝐈))ℎconditionalsubscriptsuperscript~𝑾𝑡𝑜subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖ℎ𝒩0⋅𝜎𝐈\displaystyle\;h(\widetilde{{\bm{W}}}^{(t)}_{o}\;|\;{\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i})-h({\mathcal{N}}(\bm{0},\;\sigma\cdot{\mathbf{I}}))
≤\displaystyle\leq h​(𝒩​(𝝁(t),𝚺(t)+σ⋅𝐈))−h​(𝒩​(𝟎,σ⋅𝐈)),ℎ𝒩superscript𝝁𝑡superscript𝚺𝑡⋅𝜎𝐈ℎ𝒩0⋅𝜎𝐈\displaystyle\;h({\mathcal{N}}({\bm{\mu}}^{(t)},\;{\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)}+\sigma\cdot{\mathbf{I}}))-h({\mathcal{N}}(\bm{0},\;\sigma\cdot{\mathbf{I}})), (26)

C.4 Proof of Theorem 3

Before the proof of Thm. 3, we have the following lemma.

Lemma 3.

For any d𝑑d-dimensional semi-positive definite matrix 𝐀𝐀{\bm{A}} and 𝐁𝐁{\bm{B}}, we have

  1.  (1)

    𝜶T​(𝑨+𝑩)−1​𝜶≤𝜶T​𝑨−1​𝜶,superscript𝜶Tsuperscript𝑨𝑩1𝜶superscript𝜶Tsuperscript𝑨1𝜶{\bm{\alpha}}^{\mathrm{T}}({\bm{A}}+{\bm{B}})^{-1}{\bm{\alpha}}\leq{\bm{\alpha}}^{\mathrm{T}}{\bm{A}}^{-1}{\bm{\alpha}},

  2.  (2)

    𝜶T​(𝑨+𝑩)−1​𝜶≤𝜶T​𝑩−1​𝜶,superscript𝜶Tsuperscript𝑨𝑩1𝜶superscript𝜶Tsuperscript𝑩1𝜶{\bm{\alpha}}^{\mathrm{T}}({\bm{A}}+{\bm{B}})^{-1}{\bm{\alpha}}\leq{\bm{\alpha}}^{\mathrm{T}}{\bm{B}}^{-1}{\bm{\alpha}},

where 𝛂𝛂{\bm{\alpha}} is a d𝑑d-dimensional vector.

Proof.

Here we only prove inequality (1), and the proof for inequality (2) is the same as inequality (1). First, we have

(𝑨+𝑩)−1=𝑨−1−𝑨−1​(𝑨−1+𝑩−1)−1​𝑨−1,superscript𝑨𝑩1superscript𝑨1superscript𝑨1superscriptsuperscript𝑨1superscript𝑩11superscript𝑨1({\bm{A}}+{\bm{B}})^{-1}={\bm{A}}^{-1}-{\bm{A}}^{-1}({\bm{A}}^{-1}+{\bm{B}}^{-1})^{-1}{\bm{A}}^{-1}, (29)

hence, we can get following result.

𝜶T​(𝑨+𝑩)−1​𝜶=𝜶T​(𝑨−1−𝑨−1​(𝑨−1+𝑩−1)−1​𝑨−1)​𝜶.superscript𝜶Tsuperscript𝑨𝑩1𝜶superscript𝜶Tsuperscript𝑨1superscript𝑨1superscriptsuperscript𝑨1superscript𝑩11superscript𝑨1𝜶{\bm{\alpha}}^{\mathrm{T}}({\bm{A}}+{\bm{B}})^{-1}{\bm{\alpha}}={\bm{\alpha}}^{\mathrm{T}}({\bm{A}}^{-1}-{\bm{A}}^{-1}({\bm{A}}^{-1}+{\bm{B}}^{-1})^{-1}{\bm{A}}^{-1}){\bm{\alpha}}.

Then we need to prove

𝜶T​𝑨−1​(𝑨−1+𝑩−1)−1​𝑨−1​𝜶≥0.superscript𝜶Tsuperscript𝑨1superscriptsuperscript𝑨1superscript𝑩11superscript𝑨1𝜶0{\bm{\alpha}}^{\mathrm{T}}{\bm{A}}^{-1}({\bm{A}}^{-1}+{\bm{B}}^{-1})^{-1}{\bm{A}}^{-1}{\bm{\alpha}}\geq 0. (30)

As 𝑨−1superscript𝑨1{\bm{A}}^{-1} is a symmetric matrix, we can rewrite Eq. (30) as

𝜶~T​(𝑨−1+𝑩−1)−1​𝜶~≥0,superscript~𝜶Tsuperscriptsuperscript𝑨1superscript𝑩11~𝜶0\tilde{{\bm{\alpha}}}^{\mathrm{T}}({\bm{A}}^{-1}+{\bm{B}}^{-1})^{-1}\tilde{{\bm{\alpha}}}\geq 0, (31)

where 𝜶~=𝑨−1​𝜶~𝜶superscript𝑨1𝜶\tilde{{\bm{\alpha}}}={\bm{A}}^{-1}{\bm{\alpha}}. As 𝑨𝑨{\bm{A}} and 𝑩𝑩{\bm{B}} are semi-positive definite, we have (𝑨−1+𝑩−1)−1superscriptsuperscript𝑨1superscript𝑩11({\bm{A}}^{-1}+{\bm{B}}^{-1})^{-1} is a semi-positive definite matrix either, hence inequality (31) holds, which concludes the proof. ∎

Then with Lemma 3, we can prove Thm. 3.

Proof.

As we can rewrite 𝚺isubscript𝚺𝑖{\bm{\Sigma}}_{i}, i∈{0,⋯,d−1}𝑖0⋯𝑑1i\in\{0,\cdots,d-1\}, as

=(𝑰i−1𝟎𝝆iT​𝚺i−1−11)​(𝚺i−1𝝆i𝟎ci,i−𝝆iT​𝚺i−1−1​𝝆i),absentsubscript𝑰𝑖10superscriptsubscript𝝆𝑖Tsuperscriptsubscript𝚺𝑖111subscript𝚺𝑖1subscript𝝆𝑖0subscript𝑐𝑖𝑖superscriptsubscript𝝆𝑖Tsuperscriptsubscript𝚺𝑖11subscript𝝆𝑖\displaystyle=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}{\bm{I}}_{i-1}&\mathbf{0}\\ {\bm{\rho}}_{i}^{\mathrm{T}}{\bm{\Sigma}}_{i-1}^{-1}&1\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}{\bm{\Sigma}}_{i-1}&{\bm{\rho}}_{i}\\ \mathbf{0}&c_{i,i}-{\bm{\rho}}_{i}^{\mathrm{T}}{\bm{\Sigma}}_{i-1}^{-1}{\bm{\rho}}_{i}\end{array}\right), (38)

C.5 Proof of Theorem 4

Proof.

For the first stage, if we denote the threshold of gradient clipping as S𝑆S and denote the added noise as σ⋅𝐈⋅𝜎𝐈\sigma\cdot{\mathbf{I}}, we get ‖𝒈(t)‖2≤Ssubscriptnormsuperscript𝒈𝑡2𝑆\|{\bm{g}}^{(t)}\|_{2}\leq S, where 𝒈(t)=∇𝑾F​(𝑾i(t);𝑫)superscript𝒈𝑡subscript∇𝑾𝐹subscriptsuperscript𝑾𝑡𝑖𝑫{\bm{g}}^{(t)}=\nabla_{{\bm{W}}}F({\bm{W}}^{(t)}_{i};\;{\bm{D}}) is a random vector as a function of 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}}. Hence, we have

tr⁡(𝚺(t))≤tr⁡(𝔼​(𝒈(t)​(𝒈(t))T))=𝔼​(‖𝒈(t)‖22)≤S2,trsuperscript𝚺𝑡tr𝔼superscript𝒈𝑡superscriptsuperscript𝒈𝑡𝑇𝔼subscriptsuperscriptnormsuperscript𝒈𝑡22superscript𝑆2\operatorname{\mathrm{tr}}({\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)})\leq\operatorname{\mathrm{tr}}({\mathbb{E}}({\bm{g}}^{(t)}({\bm{g}}^{(t)})^{T}))={\mathbb{E}}(\|{\bm{g}}^{(t)}\|^{2}_{2})\leq S^{2}, (43)

where the first inequality depends on the relationship between covariance matrix and the auto-correlation matrix, i.e., tr[𝔼(𝒈(t)(𝒈(t))T)−𝚺(t)]=tr[𝔼(𝒈(t))𝔼(𝒈(t))T)]≥0\operatorname{\mathrm{tr}}[{\mathbb{E}}({\bm{g}}^{(t)}({\bm{g}}^{(t)})^{T})-{\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)}]=\operatorname{\mathrm{tr}}[{\mathbb{E}}({\bm{g}}^{(t)}){\mathbb{E}}({\bm{g}}^{(t)})^{T})]\geq 0.

Then we have ∑i=1dλi(t)=tr⁡(𝚺(t))≤S2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑡𝑖trsuperscript𝚺𝑡superscript𝑆2\sum_{i=1}^{d}\lambda^{(t)}_{i}=\operatorname{\mathrm{tr}}({\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)})\leq S^{2}. Based on AM-GM inequality and the fact λi(t)≥0subscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑡𝑖0\lambda^{(t)}_{i}\geq 0, the channel capacity derived by Eq. (15) has an upper bound as

Therefore, if we treat σ𝜎\sigma as a constant, and denote uσ​(d):=d⋅ln⁡σ+S2/dσ,d≥0formulae-sequenceassignsubscript𝑢𝜎𝑑⋅𝑑𝜎superscript𝑆2𝑑𝜎𝑑0u_{\sigma}(d):=d\cdot\ln\frac{\sigma+S^{2}/d}{\sigma},d\geq 0, we have f(t)​(σ)≤uσ​(d)superscript𝑓𝑡𝜎subscript𝑢𝜎𝑑f^{(t)}(\sigma)\leq u_{\sigma}(d). We observe that uσ′​(d)=ln⁡σ+S2/dσ+σσ+S2/d−1subscriptsuperscript𝑢′𝜎𝑑𝜎superscript𝑆2𝑑𝜎𝜎𝜎superscript𝑆2𝑑1u^{{}^{\prime}}_{\sigma}(d)=\ln\frac{\sigma+S^{2}/d}{\sigma}+\frac{\sigma}{\sigma+S^{2}/d}-1. Hence

u(d)′′σ=−S2​(2​σ​d+S2)d​(σ​d+S2)2≤0⇒uσ′(d)≥uσ′(+∞)=0,u{{}^{\prime\prime}}_{\sigma}(d)=-\frac{S^{2}(2\sigma d+S^{2})}{d(\sigma d+S^{2})^{2}}\leq 0\Rightarrow u^{{}^{\prime}}_{\sigma}(d)\geq u^{{}^{\prime}}_{\sigma}(+\infty)=0,

which implies uσ​(d)subscript𝑢𝜎𝑑u_{\sigma}(d) is an increasing function of the dimension d𝑑d. Based on L’Hospital’s rule, we can conclude that

C(t)=f(t)​(σ)≤uσ​(d)≤uσ​(+∞)=S2σ.superscript𝐶𝑡superscript𝑓𝑡𝜎subscript𝑢𝜎𝑑subscript𝑢𝜎superscript𝑆2𝜎C^{(t)}=f^{(t)}(\sigma)\leq u_{\sigma}(d)\leq u_{\sigma}(+\infty)=\frac{S^{2}}{\sigma}. (44)

For the second stage, which provides a (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP, the authors in [19] demonstrate that we need to choose σ≥S2⋅2​log⁡(1.25/δ)ϵ2𝜎⋅superscript𝑆221.25𝛿superscriptitalic-ϵ2\sigma\geq S^{2}\cdot\frac{2\log(1.25/\delta)}{\epsilon^{2}}, then with a substitution in Eq. (44), we have C(t)≤ϵ22​log⁡(1.25/δ)superscript𝐶𝑡superscriptitalic-ϵ221.25𝛿C^{(t)}\leq\frac{\epsilon^{2}}{2\log(1.25/\delta)}. Hence, the channel capacity of (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP in the FL scenario is upper bounded by ϵ22​log⁡(1.25/δ)superscriptitalic-ϵ221.25𝛿\frac{\epsilon^{2}}{2\log(1.25/\delta)}.

Finally, as illustrated in [19], for mini-batch SGD in DP, i.e., the batch size B>1𝐵1B>1, the mechanism becomes 𝒈=1B​(∑i=1B𝒈¯i+𝝃)𝒈1𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐵subscript¯𝒈𝑖𝝃{\bm{g}}=\frac{1}{B}(\sum_{i=1}^{B}\bar{{\bm{g}}}_{i}+{\bm{\xi}}), let 𝒈~=1B​∑i=1B𝒈¯i~𝒈1𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐵subscript¯𝒈𝑖\tilde{{\bm{g}}}=\frac{1}{B}\sum_{i=1}^{B}\bar{{\bm{g}}}_{i} and 𝝃~=1B​𝝃~𝝃1𝐵𝝃\tilde{{\bm{\xi}}}=\frac{1}{B}{\bm{\xi}}, we have 𝚺𝒈~=1B​𝚺𝒈isubscript𝚺~𝒈1𝐵subscript𝚺subscript𝒈𝑖{\bm{\Sigma}}_{\tilde{{\bm{g}}}}=\frac{1}{B}{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{g}}_{i}} and 𝚺𝝃~=1B2​𝚺𝝃subscript𝚺~𝝃1superscript𝐵2subscript𝚺𝝃{\bm{\Sigma}}_{\tilde{{\bm{\xi}}}}=\frac{1}{B^{2}}{\bm{\Sigma}}_{{\bm{\xi}}}. By substitution them into Eq. (43), we can immediately conclude the proof. ∎

Appendix D Validating the theories of existing methods

The impact of batch size for DP and utilizing large batch size in defending against DRA. To improve the existing defense algorithm for defending against DRA, we design experiments to validate the roles of B𝐵B by gradient inversion attack on CIFAR-10. Specifically, to keep identical reconstruction difficulties for different B𝐵B, we only reconstruct one image from the gradient as the mean restoration 𝔼​[𝑫^]𝔼delimited-[]^𝑫\mathbb{E}[\hat{{\bm{D}}}]. Then we calculate the MSE between 𝔼​[𝑫^]𝔼delimited-[]^𝑫\mathbb{E}[\hat{{\bm{D}}}] and the mean value of local dataset 𝔼​[𝑫]𝔼delimited-[]𝑫\mathbb{E}[{\bm{D}}], i.e., ‖𝔼​[𝑫^]−𝔼​[𝑫]‖2superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]^𝑫𝔼delimited-[]𝑫2\|\mathbb{E}[\hat{{\bm{D}}}]-\mathbb{E}[{\bm{D}}]\|^{2}. Due to the convexity of MSE, the difference between 𝑫^^𝑫\hat{{\bm{D}}} and 𝑫𝑫{\bm{D}} is lower bounded, i.e., 𝔼​‖𝑫^−𝑫‖2≥‖𝔼​[𝑫^]−𝔼​[𝑫]‖2𝔼superscriptnorm^𝑫𝑫2superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]^𝑫𝔼delimited-[]𝑫2\mathbb{E}\|\hat{{\bm{D}}}-{\bm{D}}\|^{2}\geq\|\mathbb{E}[\hat{{\bm{D}}}]-\mathbb{E}[{\bm{D}}]\|^{2}. Moreover, we utilize clipping bound S=1.0𝑆1.0S=1.0 and the noise multiplier σ=1.3𝜎1.3\sigma=1.3 for the DP training. The results are displayed in Fig. 8. If we utilize DP for privacy protection, the performance for defending against DRA consistently decreases with an increasing B𝐵B. This phenomenon is consistent with Thm. 4, indicating that the small B𝐵B is beneficial for DP in defending against DRA.

Additionally, when we do not apply any defense technique for privacy, the defense ability increases according to the increasing B𝐵B. This phenomenon is consistent with Eq. (24) due to the intrinsic noise in the collected data. Moreover, the performance improvement becomes more significant when we add a constant noise to the parameters. The conclusion is that when we add a constant noise to the parameter, a larger B𝐵B leads to a stronger ability to defend against DRA.

The impact of eigenvalues in compression. We also validate our theories for compression on CIFAR-10 datasets. In these experiments, we utilize the gradient inversion attack to reconstruct data from the gradients. For the compression, we set the eigenvector to be 𝟎0\mathbf{0} to reduce the information in the corresponding dimension. Then we map the training data to the compressed eigenspace. For comparison, we only compress one dimension according to the eigenvalue. The results are displayed in Fig. 8. Specifically, the eigenvalues {λm​a​x,λ1,λ10}subscript𝜆𝑚𝑎𝑥subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆10\{\lambda_{max},\lambda_{1},\lambda_{10}\} are as follows: {222.21, 85.08, 9.91} for CIFAR10, {346.21, 71.01, 12.82} for CelebA, {313.0, 28.04, 4.67} for SVHN, and {101.88, 61.80, 3.21} for Fashion-MNIST. The experiment results demonstrate that the compression on the dimension with a larger eigenvalue leads to a stronger defensive ability to defend against DRA, which is consistent with our theories.

Appendix E Channel Capacities of Existing Methods

Compression. As for gradient compression, it is easy to understand that the compression mechanism reduces the information contained in parameters, and we can also formalize this intuition with our channel model.

On the one hand, in the eigenspace of 𝚺(t)superscript𝚺𝑡{\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)}, the channel capacity is C(t)=12​∑i=1dln⁡λi(t)+σσsuperscript𝐶𝑡12superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑡𝑖𝜎𝜎C^{(t)}=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{d}\ln\frac{\lambda^{(t)}_{i}+\sigma}{\sigma}, and due to the non-negativity of λi(t)subscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑡𝑖\lambda^{(t)}_{i}, ln⁡λi(t)+σσ≥0subscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑡𝑖𝜎𝜎0\ln\frac{\lambda^{(t)}_{i}+\sigma}{\sigma}\geq 0, i∈{1,⋯,d}𝑖1⋯𝑑i\in\{1,\cdots,d\}, represents the upper bound of information contained in the different independent dimensions. As illustrated in Fig. 8, if we set a positive λi(t)subscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑡𝑖\lambda^{(t)}_{i} to be 00, then the corresponding C(t)superscript𝐶𝑡C^{(t)} decreases.

On the other hand, the gradient compression is directly applied for the gradient 𝒈𝒈{\bm{g}} [38, 56], hence we need to analyze 𝚺(t)superscript𝚺𝑡{\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)} itself. Specifically, in this situation, the information contained in different dimensions is not independent, so we cannot directly analyze the information contained in each dimension. Without loss of generality, we can rewrite 𝚺(t)superscript𝚺𝑡{\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)} as

𝚺(t)=superscript𝚺𝑡absent\displaystyle{\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)}= (𝑷d−k𝑹𝑹T𝑸k)subscript𝑷𝑑𝑘𝑹superscript𝑹Tsubscript𝑸𝑘\displaystyle\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}{\bm{P}}_{d-k}&{\bm{R}}\\ {\bm{R}}^{\mathrm{T}}&{\bm{Q}}_{k}\end{array}\right) (47)
=\displaystyle= (𝑰d−k𝟎𝑹T​𝑷d−k−1𝑰k)​(𝑷d−k𝑹𝟎𝑸k−𝑹T​𝑷d−k−1​𝑹),subscript𝑰𝑑𝑘0superscript𝑹Tsuperscriptsubscript𝑷𝑑𝑘1subscript𝑰𝑘subscript𝑷𝑑𝑘𝑹0subscript𝑸𝑘superscript𝑹Tsuperscriptsubscript𝑷𝑑𝑘1𝑹\displaystyle\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}{\bm{I}}_{d-k}&\mathbf{0}\\ {\bm{R}}^{\mathrm{T}}{\bm{P}}_{d-k}^{-1}&{\bm{I}}_{k}\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}{\bm{P}}_{d-k}&{\bm{R}}\\ \mathbf{0}&{\bm{Q}}_{k}-{\bm{R}}^{\mathrm{T}}{\bm{P}}_{d-k}^{-1}{\bm{R}}\end{array}\right), (51)

where 𝑷d−k∈ℝ(d−k)×(d−k)subscript𝑷𝑑𝑘superscriptℝ𝑑𝑘𝑑𝑘{\bm{P}}_{d-k}\in\mathbb{R}^{(d-k)\times(d-k)} represents the covariance matrix of the uncompressed dimension, 𝑸k∈ℝk×ksubscript𝑸𝑘superscriptℝ𝑘𝑘{\bm{Q}}_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{k\times k} represents the covariance matrix of the compressed dimension, and 𝑹∈ℝ(d−k)×k𝑹superscriptℝ𝑑𝑘𝑘{\bm{R}}\in\mathbb{R}^{(d-k)\times k} represents the mutual covariance matrix between the compressed dimension and the uncompressed dimension. Thus, we have

det(𝚺(t))=det(𝑷d−k)⋅det(𝑸k−𝑹T​𝑷d−k−1​𝑹).superscript𝚺𝑡⋅subscript𝑷𝑑𝑘subscript𝑸𝑘superscript𝑹Tsuperscriptsubscript𝑷𝑑𝑘1𝑹\det({\bm{\Sigma}}^{(t)})=\det({\bm{P}}_{d-k})\cdot\det({\bm{Q}}_{k}-{\bm{R}}^{\mathrm{T}}{\bm{P}}_{d-k}^{-1}{\bm{R}}). (52)

Combining Eq. (52) with Thm. 2, we can conclude that the decrease of channel capacity caused by compression can be formalized as

Δ​C(t)=12​ln⁡det(𝑸k+σ​𝑰k−𝑹T​(𝑷d−k+σ​𝑰d−k)−1​𝑹)σk.Δsuperscript𝐶𝑡12subscript𝑸𝑘𝜎subscript𝑰𝑘superscript𝑹Tsuperscriptsubscript𝑷𝑑𝑘𝜎subscript𝑰𝑑𝑘1𝑹superscript𝜎𝑘\Delta C^{(t)}=\frac{1}{2}\ln\frac{\det({\bm{Q}}_{k}+\sigma{\bm{I}}_{k}-{\bm{R}}^{\mathrm{T}}({\bm{P}}_{d-k}+\sigma{\bm{I}}_{d-k})^{-1}{\bm{R}})}{\sigma^{k}}.

As the covariance matrix is positive semi-definite, we conclude that Δ​C(t)≥0Δsuperscript𝐶𝑡0\Delta C^{(t)}\geq 0.

Appendix F Additional Experiments

In this section, we display additional experimental results to evaluate our techniques. The results are summarized as follows:

  • •

    The results for White Channel and Personalized Channel. Fig. 20 and Fig. 20 display the model accuracy and the defense ability to defend against DRA for White Channel. Meanwhile, Fig. 23 and Fig. 23 display the corresponding results for Personalized Channel. Specifically, these results are similar to the Natural Channel, when we increase the channel capacity, the model accuracy increases, while the defense ability decreases.

  • •

    The defense ability for defending against MIA. The results in Fig. 20, Fig. 23, and Fig. 26 indicate that reducing channel capacity can also defend against MIA. Specifically, a smaller AUC means a stronger ability for defending against MIA, which indicates that it is difficult for an attacker to infer the membership property of the given data. When we constrain the transmitted information, the AUC for conducting MIA significantly decreases. Moreover, Fig. 26 exhibits a similar phenomenon when we restrict the optimization rounds n𝑛n. All of these results demonstrate that constraining transmitted information can also defend against MIA.

  • •

    Utility privacy tradeoff according to optimization rounds n𝑛n. Fig. 24 displays the utility privacy tradeoff according to n𝑛n. Similarly, we fix the channel capacity κ=300𝜅300\kappa=300, and vary the total transmitted information in {5×1055superscript1055\times 10^{5}, 1×1061superscript1061\times 10^{6}, 2×1062superscript1062\times 10^{6}, 3×1063superscript1063\times 10^{6}} (where n=⌊T​o​t​a​l​I​n​f​oκ⌋𝑛𝑇𝑜𝑡𝑎𝑙𝐼𝑛𝑓𝑜𝜅n=\lfloor\frac{TotalInfo}{\kappa}\rfloor, where ⌊⋅⌋⋅\lfloor\cdot\rfloor is the floor function.). Specifically, increasing n𝑛n leads to more transmitted information, thus results in the increase in utility and the decrease in the ability of privacy protection. These results demonstrate that adjusting n𝑛n can also influence the tradeoff between the utility and the privacy.

  • •

    More metrics for evaluating the ability to defend against DRA. For random variables, MSE is 00 implies the convergence in mean, which further implies convergence in distribution, i.e., the distributions of these variables are identical [58]. Meanwhile, a smaller MSE indicates the reconstructed data distribution gets closer to the target distribution. Fig. 30 displays the MSE for CelebA, SVHN, and Fashion-MNIST. The results indicate that when we constrain the transmitted information, the MSE increases, which indicates that it is more difficult for an attacker to conduct DRA attacks.
    In addition to the MSE, we also utilize other metrics such as PSNR, SSIM, and Cosine Similarity to measure the similarity between the reconstructed data and the target data. Among them, PSNR is the most popular metric to measure the quality of the processed image, SSIM is the second most popular metric for this target [33], and Cosine Similarity is the most familiar metric for us to measure the similarity of two vectors. For all of them, the larger value means more similarities in the reconstruction, which indicates the weaker ability to defend against DRA. Fig. 29 and Fig. 31 display the results of PSNR, Fig. 29 and Fig. 32 show the reconstruction error by SSIM, Fig. 29 and Fig. 33 utilize Cosine Similarity to measure the quality of reconstructed data. All of these results demonstrate that reducing channel capacity can effectively reduce the quality of reconstruction. In other words, our method can enhance the ability to defend against DRA, which is consistent with Thm. 1.
    Particularly, we put emphasis on the metric of MSE. We choose MSE as the main metric for three reasons: first, MSE indicates the convergence of random variables [58]. That is, if the MSE of two random variables is 00, we conclude that they have identical distributions, which means a perfect reconstruction. Second, Thm. 1 indicates that restricting transmitted information can provide the theoretical lower bound for MSE. Finally, MSE is a general metric for random variables.

Appendix G Discussion of the Channels

In this section, we summarize the advantages and disadvantages of the Natural Channel, the While Channel, and the Personalized Channel as follows:

  • •

    Natural Channel. It preserves the relative importance of different attributes, hence it maintains the information contained in the dataset, which is beneficial for the model utility in FL. However, Natural Channel cannot incorporate prior knowledge into the protecting process, hence we cannot adjust the algorithm according to the requirement when channel capacity is decided.

  • •

    White Channel. It provides a much stronger defense ability to defend against DRA when there is no prior knowledge. It treats the importance of each attribute to be equal, which adds more noise to the dimension with more information to achieve such stronger protection. However, the computation complexity of the White Channel is higher than the Natural Channel because of the additional matrix multiplication.

  • •

    Personalized Channel. It allows us to leverage prior knowledge of the attribute importance to the protection process, hence we can perform the better utility-privacy tradeoff. Whereas, in order to reduce the computation complexity, the Personalized Channel depends on an upper bound, which weakens this benefit accordingly.
